police_conduct_quote: If the toxicologist finds meperidine in Suzanne Morton's body, you'll be lucky if you're only deported.
quote_or_scene: Raza confesses to white-out falsification: 'I wrote meperidine without thinking. But I gave her acetaminophen... when they look at me here, they see an Indian or a Paki... I have to be twice as good as everybody else just so they will think I am as good as everybody else.'
tags: wrong_ID; witness_recant; ruined_at_work; immigrant; minority; doctor; murder_case
notes: Raza was accused of causing Morton's death through prescribing meperidine. He admitted to falsifying records with white-out to avoid narcotic paperwork but insisted he gave acetaminophen. Investigation later proved Dr. Auster (Chief of Medicine) actually administered the fatal meperidine while drunk. Raza faced deportation threats and career damage as foreign doctor trying to prove competence. Eventually cleared and offered job by Chief of Medicine before trial revealed Auster's guilt.

episode_title: Kiss the Girls and Make Them Die
police_conduct_quote: Logan: 'Did you ever hear about a new disease they got called AIDS?' Logan also calls Feinstein's magazine 'garbage' and says 'You don't know much about women, do you?' when questioning him. The detectives show clear contempt throughout.
quote_or_scene: Detectives repeatedly visit Feinstein at his workplace/studio where he publishes 'Cyber Funk' magazine. A woman is present during questioning: 'Woman: Steve? / Feinstein: I'm kind of busy right now. / Woman: You keep me waiting and I won't be interested. / Feinstein: It'll just have to wait. / Woman: Steve? Oh-hh, a foursome? / Feinstein: They're cops.' Later: 'You got it. / Logan: And you never wanted to see her again? And you told her? / Feinstein: And you didn't sleep with her? / Logan: I just did it to shut her up. / Feinstein: Why didn't you tell us? / Logan: Just to shut us up?'
notes: Feinstein was the initial primary suspect based on being seen arguing with victim and leaving bar with her. He had an alibi (dinner with investors from 9:30pm-3:30am verified by Eleanor Phipps and others). Despite alibi, detectives returned multiple times and questioned him publicly at his workplace in front of colleagues/associates. DNA testing proved he had sex with victim earlier in evening but his alibi placed him elsewhere during murder. Detectives showed clear hostility and moral judgment throughout questioning. No apology given once cleared. Qualifies as harm because he was publicly accused at his place of business, exposing him to colleagues despite having provable innocence via alibi.

police_conduct_quote: Come on, where did you unload the credit cards? ... You may just have bought yourself a ticket out of here.
quote_or_scene: Judge: Willie Tivnan. The charges are murder in the second degree, attempted murder, and assault in the first degree. ... Bail is set at $100,000. ... Stone later uses Willie's testimony to prove Janet Ralston shot her husband.
tags: arrested; public_trial; wrong_ID; witness_recant; black_man_falsely_accused; poor; drug_user; murder_case
notes: Willie was smoking crack in the stairwell when Alan Ralston was murdered. His fingerprints on the crack pipe and Janet Ralston's false identification led to his arrest. He was held on $100,000 bail and publicly arraigned. Defense attorney Elizabeth Strickland believed he was innocent. Willie's truthful account of the light going out BEFORE the door opened (contradicting the theory he shot Ralston) helped prove Janet Ralston was the actual killer. Willie admitted to eight separate muggings but consistently denied the murder. No apology is shown despite his innocence being proven and his testimony being crucial to convicting the actual killers.

police_conduct_quote: Logan: 'Hey... shut up. We don't dig being dissed by lightweights.' Then threatening about Spofford youth facility: 'I'm not talking about a year at Spofford. Going... Going... Gone.'
quote_or_scene: Simonize and Tremaine tell detectives: 'Look, he was already cut when we got there. We took him off, but we didn't do nothing to him. He started to choke. He was just lying there bleeding. It was that white cat in the Benz.' Later pleads to 'Possession of stolen property, six months.'

They confessed under pressure but maintained they didn't stab him. Their account was corroborated by truck driver Tony Hallowell who saw Scalisi at the scene. Pleaded to possession of stolen property.

police_conduct_quote: Max yells 'Drop the gun, Tremaine!' during arrest. Earlier Logan threatens: 'If the councilman croaks, you guys move up to the bigs... murder two.'
quote_or_scene: Lewis arrested at gunpoint in his apartment. Both suspects tell police about 'that white cat in the Benz' who 'got out as soon as the truck pulled off.' Trucker Tony Hallowell corroborates: 'there were two guys at the rear of the Jag... guy reaches in, pulls out a fur coat and hands it to the other guy' who gets in Mercedes.

notes: Like Jackson, Lewis was guilty only of robbery of possessions from already-wounded Halsey, but innocent of the stabbing. Their testimony about the white man in the Mercedes (Scalisi) proved accurate. Pleaded to possession of stolen property, six months.

quote_or_scene: Silky testifies: 'Tommy turns to say something, and the cop shoots him. Tommy didn't have no gun. Freddo takes my gun, he wipes it on his shirt—twice...and puts it in Tommy's hand.' Also: 'When they brought the Richardson boy to the morgue, he had $3,000 on him. The transaction never took place. He never bought Silky's gun.'
tags: murder_case; wrongful_conviction; fabricated_claim; media_outing; reputation_destroyed; cop; Princeton_student; community_hero
notes: Tommy Richardson was killed by Officer Parisi who then planted a gun on him to justify the shooting. The accusation (that Tommy drew a gun on police) was fabricated by Parisi placing his own weapon in the victim's hand. Tommy's reputation as a Princeton honors student and community benefactor was destroyed when his drug dealing activities were revealed during the investigation and trial. The public exposure occurred through media coverage ('Did you know Tommy Richardson lectured against drugs? Can you make some kind of a statement?') and courtroom proceedings. Though Tommy was involved in drug dealing (partially_involved in that crime), he was completely innocent of the accusation that killed him—attempting to shoot a police officer. His death and the destruction of his heroic reputation in the community constitute severity 4 harm.

police_conduct_quote: Freddo at Silky's cell: 'He says if I tell anybody, he'll kill me. Says it's my lucky day...Keep your mouth shut, or you're dead. Even if I burn him, his partner'll get me.'
quote_or_scene: Davis initially identifies Silky in lineup but softly: 'Could be...could be number three. I'm not sure enough for an ID.' Greevey notes: 'It's hard to believe that his gun was there and he wasn't.' Later Silky arrested: 'You have the right to remain silent.' Silky threatened by Parisi to stay silent about witnessing the shooting.
tags: murder_case; wrong_ID; witness_recant; arrested; coerced_confession; threatened_by_cop
notes: Silky Ford was briefly suspected of being present at the shooting scene when Davis and Parisi soft-identified him in a lineup, though both knew he was the actual witness who could expose Parisi's cover-up. Silky was arrested on weapons charges. Though Silky was guilty of selling the gun and drug dealing, he was innocent of participating in any shooting or drawing a weapon on police. The key harm was Parisi's direct death threats to keep him from testifying, plus his arrest. Exposure was primarily within law enforcement (police_only), but the arrest and death threats from a cop constitute material harm (severity 3). Eventually cooperated after being set up on drug charges and offered a deal.

quote_or_scene: Patrick: 'I'm not going to jail, Kevin. I can prove I wasn't involved.' Kevin: 'Mary wasn't involved either. Shut up! Shut up!' Stone: 'Hey!' Kevin: 'All he wanted was for her to be a martyr instead of a sinner. She didn't go there to bomb the clinic. She was pregnant. She was there to have an abortion... That morning I gave her the ID and the money so that she could... I pleaded with her to at least let me take her. I pleaded.'
notes: Patrick's fingerprints were on Mary's false ID card, leading to his arrest for conspiracy to bomb the clinic. In reality, he gave her the fake ID and money so she could get an abortion anonymously. He was trying to help her avoid shame with her family, not plant a bomb. He pleaded with her to let him accompany her. Exposure appears limited to police interrogation room with Kevin present; no indication of public exposure at work or to family beyond Kevin.

police_conduct_quote: Profaci: 'If it was you and walker in an alley and no one else was there, he didn't have a gun and was gonna give himself up... I'd shoot him in the face.'
quote_or_scene: Stone presents evidence to Walker and Simpson showing Rennick killed Ricky Powers, not Walker. Walker says 'Hundreds of brothers wanted him dead!' Stone eventually reveals tape proves Sandoval killed Rennick in self-defense, clearing Walker of cop-killing.
tags: wrong_ID; media_outing; arrested; cop; murder_case; public_confrontation
notes: Walker was guilty of throwing Ramos out the window and killing drug dealer Ricky Powers under coercion from Rennick, but was innocent of killing Officer Rennick. The transcript shows widespread assumption he killed the cop, leading to manhunt and arrest. He faced potential execution ('dead man' if stays on street). Detectives openly discussed shooting him on sight. He was arrested on screen for Rennick's murder before being cleared.

police_conduct_quote: Max: 'Where'd you get the gun, Ravina?' Ravina: 'Don't touch me! Don't you touch me! I don't let no man touch me.'
quote_or_scene: Greevey: 'Great, 15-year-old high school girl. Some neighborhood kid. She says she picked it up in back of the building.' Max: 'She got no motive to shoot a cop.' Greevey: 'Problem is, her prints are on the gun. Brutus walker's aren't.'
notes: 15-year-old girl found the gun and picked it up. Her fingerprints on the murder weapon led to her being questioned. She became distressed during interrogation, pulling a gun (the murder weapon) in fear before being talked down. No indication the accusation spread beyond the detectives, but she experienced coercive interrogation and significant distress. Cleared when detectives realize she had no motive and simply found the weapon.

police_conduct_quote: Any jury that sees those tapes will send you up for a lot more time than your buddies'll do. / I can only work with what I have on hand, and if your client plans to martyr himself with a heavier sentence, that's not my problem.
quote_or_scene: Ryan is 17, terrified, held at gunpoint in court by co-defendant. Initially accused as equal participant in gang rape. Later testimony reveals: 'We really didn't think he'd go through with it... We just thought we'd set him up, he'd back off, get scared.' Evidence shows he was present but Pruiting was the actual rapist.
tags: public_trial; indicted; witness_recant; coerced_confession; circumstantial_case; jailed_pretrial
notes: Ryan is partially_involved because he was present and held the victim, which is criminal. However, he was initially accused as a primary rapist (equal to Metzler/Hanauer), when the actual rape was committed by Timothy Pruiting. The harm from being publicly accused of gang rape exceeds his actual culpability (holding/accessory). He's 17 with no record, terrified, and threatened in open court. The prosecution initially treats him as equally guilty, causing severe legal/reputational harm disproportionate to his role. Eventually becomes state witness against Pruiting with reduced charges.

police_conduct_quote: We weren't able to leverage Hanauer, or Metzler, and the younger kid is not forthcoming.
quote_or_scene: Metzler confesses 'we really didn't think he'd go through with it' about Ryan. Recording from police car: 'We didn't do her. He got off on it... All we did was hold her, maybe some other stupid stuff, but we're not riding down for Pruiting.' Narcotics says Metzler has been 'running for [Pruiting] for months.'
notes: Metzler is partially_involved as an accessory who held the victim during Pruiting's rape. Initially charged as equal participant/co-rapist in gang rape. The actual penetration/primary assault was committed by Timothy Pruiting. Metzler's criminal conduct (holding victim, being present) is real but distinct from the rape itself. Public accusation as gang rapist causes legal/reputational harm exceeding actual role. Eventually case dismissed then re-filed with more accurate understanding of roles.

police_conduct_quote: We weren't able to leverage Hanauer, or Metzler.

notes: Hanauer is partially_involved as accessory who held the victim during Pruiting's rape. Initially charged as equal participant in gang rape. Hanauer's role was holding the victim and being present - criminal but not the primary rape offense for which he was publicly accused and indicted. Case dismissed then re-filed with corrected understanding of each defendant's role.

quote_or_scene: GREEVEY: 'There is no way he could be charged with any crime let alone serve any time.' DEFENSE ATTORNEY: 'I'm sure you gentlemen are familiar with the word "incompetent."' GREEVEY: 'Yeah, well, from where I sit he's competent enough to do 3½-to-10 years.' Later cleared when HOOVER says: 'I saw a guy come out the back in the alley. Mean looking. Fancy suit. Like Donald Trump.' He later IDs Pilefsky: 'That's the guy. Etched in stone.'
notes: Hoover was found with $112 from the register and was initially treated as a suspect. He was homeless and mentally ill, making him an easy target. However, he consistently maintained he saw someone else and later identified Pilefsky. He was cleared but died shortly after in a hotel from alcohol, which the detectives had provided. His exposure was limited to police interrogation room with his defense attorney present. No public exposure or material harm beyond the interrogation itself, so severity is 1.

police_conduct_quote: The DA's subpoena is a powerful weapon. If I have to I will question every landlord of every building you inspected over a decade. One of them, I assure you, will turn you in to protect his own good name.
quote_or_scene: Stone: 'If you testify you get immunity. If you don't, you go to prison. I'm sure the former is preferable, don't you think?'
notes: McGinty is actually guilty of bribery, but she is innocent of any involvement in murders or organized crime beyond being bought off by Beigal. She is threatened and coerced into testifying. Given she is guilty of the crime she's accused of, she does not qualify as a false accusation victim under the rubric.

police_conduct_quote: Logan: 'I got this friend over at The Post, hasn't had a hot story for months. I bet it would be a big boost to his career if I gave him an exclusive on how Joe Pilefsky ratted out Frank Masucci. What do you think, Max? Old Joe here would be breathing another, what, five, maybe six days? Nah, three tops.'
quote_or_scene: Pilefsky is convicted of assault. Police then threaten to plant a newspaper story saying he ratted on Masucci, and stage a 'Judas kiss' from D'Agastino in prison yard to make it appear he's cooperating, forcing him into witness protection.
notes: Pilefsky is guilty of the assault he's convicted of. He is also guilty of perjury from Part 1. He does not qualify as falsely accused. His coercion by police is notable but he is not innocent of his charged crimes.

quote_or_scene: Max: 'We need a motive. Was Gregory involved with... with what? Drugs?' Denise: 'Wednesday and Thursday nights, Saturday mornings, Gregory plays basketball. Monday and Tuesday nights, he got choir practice. Gregory ain't perfect, but he ain't into no dope. I can guarantee you that.' Later, Coach confirms: 'Gregory Winters was a classic point guard... Kid was the brains of this team... He thought those guys [gang members] were lame.' Max later says: 'I'm sorry.'
notes: Gregory is a 12-year-old shooting victim who falls into a coma. While he's unconscious and unable to defend himself, detectives theorize to his grieving mother that he might be a drug dealer, causing her additional pain. The accusation is made in front of his mother, who forcefully defends him. The coach and further investigation prove Gregory was a good kid focused on basketball and choir. Max offers a partial apology ('I'm sorry') but it's brief. The harm is the emotional distress caused to the mother and the insult to Gregory's character during a traumatic time.

police_conduct_quote: Max: 'Your ass is grass, hombre. You're on parole. You can't hang with felons. Even dead ones.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Cartagena based on witness Anita's statement that 'Hector said Jose was no good to his friends. He was mad, he wanted to kill him.' Later released when evidence points to Nicky Guzman.
notes: Cartagena arrested publicly at his residence with backup. Threatened with parole violation. Released when investigation shifted to Nicky Guzman. Has extensive criminal record but proven innocent of this murder.

quote_or_scene: Bailiff: 'The charges are murder in the second degree and conspiracy in the first degree.' Judge later dismisses: 'In the interest of justice, I'm dismissing on the girl.'

notes: Lucy Rivers' sister, works for church. Arrested publicly in front of family for allegedly luring Urbano from church fair. Charged with murder 2 and conspiracy. Held on $100,000 bail she could not afford. Charges dismissed by judge after grandmother's testimony revealed Nicky Guzman as actual shooter. Stone used her arrest strategically to pressure grandmother into testifying. Legal Aid lawyer Shambala Green noted this was done 'to force her to talk.'

Despite lack of solid evidence connecting him to the actual murders, he was arrested publicly. Stone eventually realizes the sons are innocent and drops charges when Petrovich is identified as the real killer through witness testimony and organized crime investigation.

consequence_detail: arrested, publicly named as suspect, trial by media, social ostracism ('People stare on the street. Far as a lot of people are concerned, we'll always be guilty.')

Earlier, Nick explains the family history: 'Mr. Jarmon was beating Gregory with a cane. Nick had to put a stop to it. And so he hit him.'

notes: Nick had previously broken his father's jaw defending his younger brother Greg from a beating with a cane. This history of violence against the abusive father made him appear guilty. He was arrested alongside Greg based purely on circumstantial evidence (weak alibi, motive of inheritance, family dynamics). Charges dropped when real killer Petrovich identified. Stone acknowledges: 'The system makes mistakes' and promises: 'We are not going to re-indict.'

quote_or_scene: Max: 'Pay up!' Logan shows Montez's sheet: 'Twice, murder two. Both by strangulation.' Coroner on Mustafa: 'Crushed larynx, broken windpipe, strangulation.' But later McCarter testifies: 'The organization told me to shut the Cuban's gob before he talked about O'Connell killing the Arab.' Montez was killed to prevent testimony, implying he was not Mustafa's killer.
notes: Montez was a federal prisoner with violent history, making him initial prime suspect for Mustafa's murder based on MO match. However, McCarter's testimony reveals Montez was killed specifically to prevent him from testifying that O'Connell killed Mustafa, strongly implying Montez was innocent of Mustafa's murder. He was murdered (severity 4) as consequence of being a potential witness against O'Connell.

quote_or_scene: IAD: 'How long they been in there? About an hour. Internal Affairs?' Max asks what gives, Cragen responds: 'These guys taking a run at the whole precinct? No, just me.' Later, Stone threatens: 'I'm going to have you up on departmental charges, friend.' Cragen proves innocence by wearing wire that gets O'Farrell's confession.
notes: Cragen was under formal IAD investigation with colleagues aware. He faced threat of indictment and departmental charges. Property clerk sign-in logs showing his presence two days in a row made him primary suspect. Stone explicitly threatened to indict him to pressure cooperation. Cleared when he wore wire proving O'Farrell's guilt. Stone acknowledges afterward: 'You did your best. I had to push you. I had no choice.'

police_conduct_quote: LOGAN: 'With a nicer apartment than yours.' CERRETA: 'Hey, listen, everybody's a suspect until they're cleared.' LOGAN: 'Your girlfriend liked a lot more than the view.' LOGAN: 'Hey... up yours, pal.'
quote_or_scene: STONE: 'Okay, we'll dismiss on the boyfriend. Pick her up.' Earlier: 'Douglas Phillips, you're under arrest for the murder of Edward Cullen and Alexandra Beckett.' Court scene: 'Not guilty. Your Honor, these are vicious murders committed by a privileged young man...' Judge: '$200,000.' Later dismissed when Melanie Cullen arrested.

notes: Phillips was arrested, bail set at $200k, publicly accused in court of being 'a privileged young man who considers himself beyond the norms of society.' Charges dismissed when new evidence pointed to Melanie Cullen. No apology shown on screen. Police were verbally aggressive during interrogation.

consequence_detail: arrested, jailed, forced medication causing severe side effects, mental deterioration, institutionalized in psychiatric facility
police_conduct_quote: Stand up. Your psychiatrist tells me that you have moments of rational thought. Now we're gonna go back in there, and we'll take care of you... and you... are gonna have one of those moments.
quote_or_scene: Stone pressures Tatum to testify despite his terror: 'James is going to kill me, don't you understand?! He's gonna slice me! He's gonna feed me to the pigeons!' Final scene reveals his fate: 'So does Lemonhead... rubber cell at Bellevue.' Dr. Olivet earlier warned: 'The man's on anti-psychotics... which leaves him nauseous, listing to one side, and in danger of choking to death on his own tongue... the guy's hurting, and I don't think he can survive another circus.'
tags: wrongful_conviction; jailed_pretrial; public_trial; arrested; mental_illness; coerced_testimony; institutionalized; ruined_physically; homeless; witness_became_accused
notes: Tatum was homeless and severely mentally ill (psychotic, not psychopathic per Dr. Olivet). Initially arrested for murder based on ring found in his jacket. He claimed it was given to him by James Polesky. Police/prosecution coerced his testimony despite his deteriorating mental state. Though he accepted a plea deal (rob two) and testified against Polesky, the process destroyed him. He ended up institutionalized at Bellevue in a 'rubber cell' - a life-altering consequence. The harm (arrest, detention, forced medication, mental deterioration, institutionalization) directly resulted from being wrongly accused of murder, even though he was later proven innocent and the real killer (Polesky) was convicted.

quote_or_scene: David Alcott, you are under arrest for the murder of the unborn son of Amy Newhouse. [...] Excuse me, you just can't walk in without an appointment! [...] This is absurd, Your Honor. These charges... [arrested publicly at his law office, tried in court, $100,000 bail set]
tags: perp_walk; public_trial; arrested; business_exec; lawyer; fabricated_claim; ruined_at_work; ruined_in_family; ruined_financially; wrongful_conviction
notes: Amy and Chris fabricated the entire case against Alcott. They knew Chris was the father (confirmed by doctor 12/19), but made Alcott believe the baby was his to blackmail him. Chris staged the attack on Amy (his alibi was proven false via odometer records). Alcott was arrested publicly at his office in front of colleagues, tried publicly for murder/assault, faced $100K bail, had assets frozen, wife filed for divorce. Though murder charges were eventually dismissed on statute technicality (fetus age), he endured full public prosecution. The harm to his reputation, marriage, finances, and career was severe and lasting despite being completely innocent of the attack.

police_conduct_quote: I know how it is, Chris. She ticks you off, so maybe you lose your temper. It happens all the time. Maybe I hit her once, but that was a long time ago [...] Hey, I know how tough it is raising a family. You're broke, you're young... The last thing you need...
quote_or_scene: Chris was initially suspected but had an apparent alibi (cab fare to Kennedy airport). Detectives used coercive tactics during interrogation. Later proven he faked the alibi and was actually guilty of staging the attack.
notes: Chris was initially a suspect but is EXCLUDED from person_rows because he was actually guilty of the crime (staged the attack on Amy as part of their fraud scheme). His false alibi was later exposed via odometer discrepancies. Including only for documentation purposes; not counted as falsely accused innocent person.

quote_or_scene: Reverend: 'In the case of the missing boy? He was never charged... my understanding of the law, that makes him innocent.' Conover to detectives: 'In most people's eyes, a lot of them, he was automatically guilty.' Conover: 'suspicion almost destroyed Conover's life.' Messimer: 'Six months later... some kid, 14, 15, says Messimer made a pass. The boy who made the accusation, he was trouble... was wanting attention.'
tags: red_herring; community_member; false_informant; ruined_in_family; CSA_accusation; witness_recant
notes: Conover was initially suspected in Tommy Keegan's 1962 disappearance by police (Detectives McFadden and Shelby). Later accused of approaching a boy at St. Lucius Church youth group where he was a counselor. The reverend states the accusing boy 'was trouble' and 'wanting attention.' Conover describes how 'suspicion almost destroyed' his life. The exposure was community-wide (church, neighbors, employer Herald House). By episode's end, Messimer confesses to killing Tommy, fully exonerating Conover regarding the murder. The church accusation is also implied false based on reverend's and Conover's statements. Severity 3: career and reputation damage, though he survived into old age (now in nursing home).

quote_or_scene: Lawlers: 'Two men... a couple. We wondered, but we thought it was awful to suspect them at first.' Messimers: 'We wouldn't want to speak ill of them, the way they were, but...' McFadden: 'You got a gay couple in the file? Two guys... 30s, 40s... lived on the block. Connors, Conway, something like that. The other guy... some German name. Couldn't make the case?'
notes: Dorfman lived with Ed Conover in the same building as victim Tommy Keegan. Detective McFadden's notes from 1962 identify them as suspects ('gay couple in the file'). Neighbors (Lawlers, Messimers) suspected them based on sexual orientation. Died 9 years before episode (1983/1984), so not directly re-investigated, but was subjected to 1962 police scrutiny and neighborhood suspicion. Messimer's confession clears both men. Severity 2: public neighborhood suspicion and police investigation, though no arrest/charges found in transcript.

police_conduct_quote: Listen. According to witnesses, you made a big stink last night around 11:00 p.m. What did you do after that? ... All right, let's go. ... Where were you all that time? ... Come on, Ruiz, think.
quote_or_scene: Landlord: 'Last night, sir, did you let Mr. Ruiz into the apartment?' Landlord: 'He said he lost his keys again... About 11:30. The news was just ending.' Logan: 'Do you know if Mr. Ruiz went out again last night?' Landlord: 'No way. That borrachon was dead to the world.'
tags: wrong_ID; witness_recant; arrested; blue_collar; immigrant; murder_case
notes: Ruiz was the initial suspect based on witness reports that he was a drunk ex-boyfriend who threatened the club after being thrown out. He was arrested and questioned. His landlord provided a clear alibi that he returned home at 11:30 PM (before the fire at 1:00-1:15 AM) and was 'dead to the world.' No evidence of public exposure beyond the arrest itself. Police moved on to other suspects once the alibi was established.

police_conduct_quote: Disposing of a body? That's obstruction and accessory to murder.
quote_or_scene: Logan and Cerreta confront Mario at his restaurant in front of staff: 'You guys don't know when to let up.' Detectives threaten him with obstruction charges for body found in his freezer. Mario responds: 'I freaked out a little bit, okay?' and 'This ain't ours. We didn't whack this guy.'
notes: Mario Forcelli owns the restaurant where Foster's body was stored in a freezer. Detectives initially suspect mob involvement due to his family connections (father ran numbers, uncle under racketeering indictment). He was publicly confronted at his workplace and threatened with charges. Later proven innocent when brother-in-law Gabriel Hunt confesses to storing the body for the actual killer (driver Lloyd Danner). Mario had been in Curacao when body was discovered and had no knowledge of the murder.

police_conduct_quote: Making me run on my bad knee. I didn't do anything. Your mother's looking for you. You're under arrest.
quote_or_scene: Ethan arrested at teacher's memorial service: 'Fin, he's coming right at you. I got him. Move! Making me run on my bad knee.' Then read Miranda rights in public.

notes: Ethan was a model student who owed his college scholarship to victim. Accused based on being last known person with victim and having her photo (given to him by Marcus Cole). Mother had been searching for him. Police used coercive tactics in interrogation ('line up the dogs'). Later cleared when he explained Marcus Cole gave him the photo and his story about the tutoring session argument was verified.

notes: Surgeon at Bellevue. Initially lied about relationship with victim (claimed mentoring program, actually met at sex club). Brother identified him as victim's boyfriend. Police questioned him at work (workplace exposure implied). Subject to coercive interrogation tactics suggesting he forced himself on victim. His lawyer intervened. Later cleared when alibi verified - doorman confirmed he came home at 10pm and didn't leave until morning. Had to reveal affair and sex club activities to clear himself, potentially exposing marriage issues.

notes: 17-year-old student with criminal record (shoplifting, assault, drugs). Ethan identified him as source of victim's nude photo from internet. Had motive (victim wouldn't graduate him) and had spread photo to harass her. Detectives confronted him on street corner in his neighborhood. Willingly agreed to blood test, which presumably cleared him ('that was too easy' suggests test ruled him out). No formal arrest shown but was clearly under suspicion and questioned.

Though cleared as suspect, his affair is exposed to his wife and he faces family consequences. Later reluctantly testifies at trial despite wanting to protect his marriage and reputation.

Evidence suggests he's a red herring - he found jewelry Ryder planted to frame the serial mugger. While guilty of pawning stolen property and prior muggings, appears innocent of Lois Ryder's murder. Exposure limited to police/legal system (no indication of media coverage), but arrested and pressured.

notes: Hellems was accused by victim's family and lawyer Fischel of performing unnecessary surgery (could have used drugs instead) and killing Roberto through the failed pacemaker. He faces multimillion-dollar lawsuits. Later proven innocent when investigation shows the pacemaker failure was due to defective leads from BioNorm, not his surgical decision. He did implant a used pacemaker but tested it and believed it safe. The real cause was manufacturing defect unrelated to recycling.

notes: Suiter was arrested and indicted for murder two after detectives discovered he altered expiration dates on recycled pacemakers. Bail set at $100,000. However, FDA expert testimony proved the pacemaker didn't fail due to battery expiration (Suiter's fraud) but due to corroded leads (manufacturing defect). Judge dismissed murder charges, acknowledging Suiter's fraud was not the cause-in-fact of death. Stone acknowledged: 'You can't fight with the FDA.' Suiter faced fraud charges instead. His arrest and indictment were public, causing reputational and business harm before exoneration on murder.

notes: Stark was arrested twice for Dawn Bryan's murder. First arrest had insufficient evidence (witness couldn't ID him, no weapon). Second arrest after his fingerprints found on gun clip retrieved from sewer pipe. Bail set at $500,000. He refused to plead guilty despite facing 25-to-life, insisting on his innocence and that he had given the gun to Dawn for protection. This turned out to be true. Dawn's father Fred Bryan planted the gun in the sewer pipe after reading in newspapers it was 'Stark's gun.' Virginia Bryan confessed to mercy-killing her daughter at Dawn's request. Stark faced public courtroom arraignment and was held on serious bail for a crime he didn't commit. Case was built around fabricated evidence (planted gun) combined with legitimate but misleading evidence (his prints on clip from when he gave her the gun).

Stone later proved his innocence by showing the actual killer was Captain Bunker. Walters was cleared through the civilian trial that proved the timeline made his guilt impossible.

notes: Paul Crandall was arrested and arraigned for Kathy McKenna's murder based on threatening TDD transcripts. His attorney explicitly states this was a 'public arrest' that humiliated him. The charges were later dismissed when linguistic analysis proved the threats were written by a hearing person (Dr. Bryce), not Crandall who is deaf. His employer and the deaf community were aware of the accusation. The defense attorney's statement about the 'spectacle' of the arrest confirms significant public exposure and reputational harm, though we don't see specific consequences like job loss on-screen.

police_conduct_quote: You ever hassle with him? ... Now we're gonna want to talk to him later maybe. / (At station) People are gonna say you clobbered Kirk and took his card. / But we're gonna have to keep you here, until we can ask him.
quote_or_scene: KELLEY: Come on. Hey, I'm walking. I'm cooperating. / LOGAN: You wanted a guy in a red hat? Meet George Siddell. ... (Later at station) BRISCOE: People are gonna say you clobbered Kirk and took his card. SIDDELL: No, I didn't. He gave it to me, a long time ago. LOGAN: Yeah. I'm sure he did. But we're gonna have to keep you here, until we can ask him.
notes: Siddell was brought in because he wore a red hat (matching witness description) and had Kirk's Medicaid card. He was questioned and detained briefly but released when he explained he'd used the card to buy pills he then sold for wine. No public exposure beyond police interaction. Excluded from final count as harm was minimal (severity 1, police_only exposure).

quote_or_scene: Search warrant execution at his home with wife present. Lawyer called. Blood found on slippers. Arrested and arraigned: 'Docket number 63181. People v. Steven R. Creighton. The charges are attempted murder in the second degree, assault in the first degree.' Bail set at $150,000. Defense attorney: 'The People's case is predicated on the testimony of an insane person.' Later dropped when Prosky identified Morrissey as attacker.
notes: Creighton was innocent of the attack but guilty of failure to report (he administered CPR then left without waiting for paramedics or reporting, fearing lawsuit). He was arrested for attempted murder based on elderly witness (Mrs. Bundy) seeing him in bathrobe in alley, Kirk identifying 'bald woman' (Creighton is bald, wore bathrobe), and blood on his slippers. Search warrant executed at his home in front of wife. Formally charged and arraigned with $150,000 bail. Charges eventually dropped when Prosky identified Morrissey. Public exposure included: home search (family present), arraignment (public court record), and his lawyer had to defend him. Clear material harm from false murder charge.

police_conduct_quote: STONE: We could be looking at a conspiracy charge here. ... He acted as a lookout for Harold Morrissey. That's enough to make him an accomplice.
quote_or_scene: STONE: Mr. Prosky, we could be looking at a conspiracy charge here. SIRKIN (lawyer): Based on what? Answering the phone? STONE: He acted as a lookout for Harold Morrissey. That's enough to make him an accomplice. PROSKY: But I didn't do anything. SIRKIN: Leon, please. STONE: I can see a light touch doesn't come naturally to you. What are you offering?
notes: Prosky was threatened with conspiracy/accomplice charges for allegedly acting as lookout. He initially lied to police about calling paramedics and his role. He was NOT innocent of wrongdoing (he witnessed the attack, lied initially, and may have facilitated it by telling Morrissey Kirk's location). However, he was innocent of the PRIMARY accusation (conspiracy to commit attempted murder). The harm was the legal threat and having to come in with lawyer. Marked partially_involved because he did lie and may have enabled the attack, but the conspiracy charge itself appears to have been leverage. Borderline for inclusion - the actual wrong (lying to police, not helping) is different from the threatened charge (conspiracy).

police_conduct_quote: BRISCOE: 'Allah calls, I hear you people get antsy.'
quote_or_scene: FBI Agent Garrett arrives and says: 'His story checks. He was with Kenny, Dukes, and Fried of State all morning.' The detectives learn the car was stolen and Asalam was in meetings during the bombing.
notes: While Asalam was brought in for questioning and subjected to an offensive religious comment by Briscoe, there is no evidence of public exposure beyond the police station or material consequences. The FBI immediately confirms his alibi. Excluded from count as exposure was police_only with minimal harm (severity 1, no public exposure, no material sanction).

police_conduct_quote: You want to find a maid, talk to other maids... Maybe we better talk this over down at the INS. You do have your green card, don't you?
quote_or_scene: Defense attorney cross-examination: 'Miss Gonzales, you and your boyfriend, Felix Ortega, broke into Mrs. Bauer's apartment the day she died, didn't you?' Maria: 'We wanted to see if she was all right.' Defense: 'You were arrested for burglary, weren't you?' Maria: 'Yes.' Defense: 'Mrs. Bauer's silver candlesticks were found in Mr. Ortega's apartment, were they not?' Maria: 'Yes.' ... Maria later testifies she was scheduled to be deported yesterday and prosecution intervened.
tags: wrong_ID; immigrant; poor; witness_becomes_accused; INS_weaponized; public_trial; charges_dropped
notes: Maria was Laura Bauer's grandmother's live-in maid who was fired Tuesday for giving extra food to starving grandmother. When she and boyfriend Felix returned Friday to check on grandmother and retrieve medicine, they found her dead. Initially suspected of burglary when silver candlesticks found at boyfriend's apartment. She claims grandmother gave them to her. Arrested for burglary, charges later dropped when prosecution realizes Laura is the actual killer. However, Maria faced deportation proceedings that were only suspended so she could testify against Laura. Laura herself called INS anonymously to get Maria deported, knowing Maria was a witness to the starvation. Cross-examination weaponized her arrest, the candlesticks, and deportation status to undermine credibility as witness.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives to Felix: 'You mind if we come in and look around?' Felix: 'You got a warrant? I know the law.' Detective: 'Look, we don't find anything, you're in the clear.' Other detective: 'Yeah, don't do us any favors. Hey, did we forget to mention? Your other girlfriend said hi.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives find $400 cash and package addressed to nephew in Dominican Republic at Felix's apartment. Detective sarcastically: 'Somebody been to the pawn shop since yesterday?' Felix: 'I work the trucks. I save my money.' Then candlesticks are identified by victim's friend. Felix has 'two burglary convictions' per detective discussion.
notes: Felix came with Maria on Friday to check on grandmother after Maria was fired. They broke down door when grandmother didn't answer, found her dead, fled. Candlesticks found at his apartment. Has prior burglary record which made him automatic suspect. Police used threat of girlfriend Rosa's immigration status and mentioned his 'other girlfriend' to pressure him. Charges eventually dropped when real killer (Laura) identified. Exposure appears limited to police encounter and search, no indication of public/workplace exposure.

consequence_detail: arrested, prosecuted, pled guilty to reduced charge with suspended sentence, psychiatric treatment ordered, reputation damaged
quote_or_scene: Dorothy Baxter arrested at her sister's house holding the baby: 'No, this is my baby though. I'm telling you.' She pleads guilty but says in court: 'we did everything that we were supposed to do. We gave her money, we took care of her... I want to know where it says that you need a backyard to love your baby.'

notes: Baxter technically committed the crime (took baby from hospital) but the episode frames her sympathetically as a victim of Debra Elkins' fraud. She believed she had a valid contract and had paid substantial money. Stone and psychiatrist Olivet both express sympathy. The 'harm' is her arrest, prosecution, financial ruin ($60k+ spent on multiple failed adoptions), and emotional devastation. Classified as partially_involved because she did take the baby, but the primary accusation (that she's a dangerous kidnapper/criminal) is shown to be unfair - she's portrayed as mentally/emotionally broken by repeated adoption scams.

consequence_detail: publicly questioned at home by detectives in front of family, threatened with job loss

Walinsky: 'That girl, she was sick. She told me to take her to the hospital. I swear to you, there was no baby.' Dispatcher earlier threatened: 'If he doesn't recover by tomorrow, you tell him, don't bother.'
notes: Walinsky is quickly cleared but detectives confront him at home in accusatory manner while he's holding his own infant son. The dispatcher had already threatened his job for calling in sick. Public exposure was moderate (family present, job threatened) but brief.

police_conduct_quote: Logan: 'You always let your girlfriends bleed half to death in a cab?' Briscoe: 'Listen, dumping that kid somewhere was gonna make your life a hell of a lot easier, wasn't it?' Shaw: 'You're wrong, man, all right? Just ask Debbie. You'll see.' Logan: 'If it was me, and I found out she was pregnant... man, I would've grabbed my hat and split.'
quote_or_scene: Shaw arrested in hotel room with baby. Logan reads him Miranda rights. During interrogation, detectives suggest he abandoned the baby to make his life easier. Shaw protests his innocence and asks to talk to Debbie. Later cleared when Debbie confirms she left the baby with him intentionally.
notes: Shaw was caring for the baby as requested by Debbie but was treated as kidnapper/accomplice. Arrested and subjected to accusatory interrogation. Detectives used insults and psychological pressure ('if it was me... I would've grabbed my hat and split'). Cleared once Debbie explained the situation.

quote_or_scene: THAYER: 'Ms. Kincaid was constantly asking about my marriage... She began to kiss my neck. I asked her to stop... She threatened to tell my wife that we were having an affair.' // KINCAID: 'He became very possessive, unreasonable... and when I wanted to break it off, he became threatening.' // 'I understand you've been censured.' quote_or_scene: LOGAN: 'So, Ronny, do you own a bicycle?' BLOCKER: 'Owned a Mongoose. Hey, those are silver, aren't they? Polished aluminum with full suspension. Somebody stole it.' // 'Blocker's got a perfect alibi. Fifty guests put him at his gallery from dawn to dusk on the day of the zoo trip.'
notes: Blocker was investigated as initial suspect due to nasty note sent to Janet Rudman after being fired, ownership of silver bicycle matching witness description, and grudge motive. Detectives questioned him at his gallery (public workplace exposure). Cleared by airtight alibi - 50 witnesses placed him at gallery exhibition all day during the zoo incident.

quote_or_scene: Detectives initially suspect Domingo of Angel's murder based on proximity and Mrs. Abel's identification. Later cleared when evidence shows Kevin Parker fired the fatal shot. 'Juan Domingo was there, too. Right next to him. We thought maybe you could tell us why, huh?'
notes: Domingo is a gun dealer who actually did shoot Ricky Morales, but was falsely accused of killing Angel Ramirez. He was arrested for Angel's murder but this charge was dropped when Kevin Parker was identified as the shooter. Domingo later becomes prosecution witness but is killed before trial. His arrest for Angel's murder qualifies as false accusation harm, though exposure stayed within police/legal channels.

Detectives threaten: 'If we find out this gun was used to commit a crime... you're looking at accessory to murder.' Billy taken to precinct for fingerprinting in front of school officials. Mother present: 'They don't wanna arrest you. Just tell them who the guns belong to.'
notes: 16-year-old student who held guns for other students. Locker searched publicly at Saint Matthews school with Monsignor and security present. Threatened with accessory to murder charges in front of school officials and mother. Taken to precinct. Later cleared when Billy reveals the gun belonged to Ricky Morales and Kevin Parker. Though not formally charged, suffered public humiliation at school and coercive interrogation.

quote_or_scene: Detectives question Manning at Hudson Polytech nuclear reactor lab, interrogate him about divorce and girlfriend, suggest physicists make bombs. Manning responds: 'Given enough time and money, I could possibly build you an atomic bomb. I know nothing of conventional explosives.'
notes: Manning was the primary suspect due to bitter divorce, new girlfriend, and technical capability to build bombs. Detectives questioned him multiple times at his workplace (nuclear reactor lab) in front of colleagues. He was later cleared when evidence pointed to Max Weiss. However, Manning also committed scientific theft against Weiss, creating complex dual-victim scenario.

consequence_detail: arrested, publicly questioned at workplace (florist), interrogated 16+ hours by Queens police, re-arrested, jailed at Rikers without bail, media exposure threatened
police_conduct_quote: Because you're a sick bastard who gets his hee-haw's out of killing innocent people... They're gonna pitch a tent outside your mother's house and they're gonna dig up every piece of dirt... We'll keep you here 16 hours or 16 days. We don't care.

Is it possible he was in both places? Sure, with a pair of wings and a good tail wind. Otherwise, he'd need at least 15 minutes to get up to Riverdale.' I didn't kill anybody.'

notes: Transcript truncated before final resolution, but strong evidence of innocence: (1) physical impossibility of being at two crime scenes 15 minutes apart; (2) no weapon found matching murder (.44); (3) ADA expresses doubt about guilt; (4) refused to confess despite extreme pressure; (5) mother vouches for character; (6) prior 16-hour Queens interrogation yielded nothing. Public exposure includes: detectives visiting workplace (florist on Woodhaven), arrest at work in front of colleagues, threatened media exposure ('6:00 news... pitch a tent outside your mother's house'), remanded without bail at public arraignment. Severity 3 due to arrest, jailing, public court appearance, workplace exposure, and intense interrogation tactics.

consequence_detail: arrested, arraigned, remanded without bail, publicly tried

notes: Papa Doc is arrested, arraigned without bail, and publicly tried for Benny Williams' murder. The case relies heavily on Joey Lang's testimony that Papa Doc was the last person with Benny alive. However, investigation reveals Pat Williams lied about his gambling and has two unexplained hours plus phone calls to his father the night of the murder. Stone discusses dismissing all charges against Papa Doc. The transcript ends before resolution, but the dialogue strongly implies Papa Doc is being wrongly prosecuted and Pat may be the actual killer. Papa Doc's profession as a bookmaker made him an easy target, but the evidence increasingly points away from him.

quote_or_scene: Berger testifies: 'Any middle-aged white person... who says that he's not frightened... no, make that terrified... to find himself alone on a city street... being followed by two or three black teenagers... is a liar.' Earlier: 'I was scared. That's why I'm here now.' Forensics expert: 'By comparing the coefficient of friction to the gross vehicular weight... he's doing 20, maybe 25.' Reverend Ott's eyewitness Bobby claims '50 mph' but grand jury refuses to indict. Stone: 'The forensic evidence contradicts an eyewitness account.'
tags: grand_jury_appearance; media_outing; public_confrontation; witness_recant; fabricated_claim; business_exec; murder_case; circumstantial_case
notes: Berger is accused of murder/manslaughter after hitting Damon Fox. Forensic evidence (skid marks, speed calculation) proves he was traveling 20-25 mph, not speeding. Eyewitness Bobby (later revealed to be coached by Reverend Ott) fabricated testimony claiming 50 mph. Grand jury hears both versions and refuses to indict for homicide. Berger pleads to leaving the scene only. However, he faces significant public exposure: appears before grand jury, questioned by prosecutors, leaves courthouse through rear door due to crowd threats, later testifies in Roberts trial where he's publicly confronted about his fear of blacks. His business reputation and community standing are damaged. The fabricated accusation triggers citywide riots. Severity 3 due to grand jury appearance, media exposure, community threats requiring police protection, and being central figure in racial controversy.

quote_or_scene: Korey Burke at lineup: 'No. I don't think it's any of them... No. He's not there.' Detective confirms: 'You're absolutely sure?' Burke: 'Yes.' Then released.
notes: Obsessed fan with stalking history and threatening letter ('If you won't play for me, I hope you never play again'). Detectives bring him in based on letter and past incident trying to force into locker room. He voluntarily submits to lineup wanting victim 'to see me.' Victim definitively clears him. No indication exposure went beyond police. Released immediately after lineup.

quote_or_scene: Stone to Kincaid: 'We know who did it, but we have no evidence proving it.' Coach: 'The papers have ripped her apart. She's been punished enough.' Defense attorney Joan: 'Mr. Kenner's a jerk. Two months ago, I had to call the cops to toss him out of my apartment... Why? Motive's not part of the prima facie case. But nine times out of ten, lack of it translates into reasonable doubt.' Prosecutors shift theory to Mitchell Burke or Korey herself as actual perpetrators.
tags: wrong_ID; coerced_confession; public_trial; media_outing; perp_walk; prosecutorial_overreach; reputation_destroyed; career_destroyed
notes: Tennis player ranked #82, accused of hiring Marc Kenner to attack rival Korey Burke (#5 ranked). Sole evidence is Kenner's confession obtained through police deception (fake forensics), which judge suppresses. Defense attorney correctly notes complete lack of motive - attacking Burke doesn't help Hall's career ('I beat Number 81, who cares?'). Prosecutors acknowledge 'crime doesn't make sense' and later develop alternative theories (Burke's father or Korey self-harm). Hall arrested on-court in front of media/crowd, charged with assault 1st degree and conspiracy, bail $100k. Media coverage ('papers have ripped her apart'). Transcript ends with prosecutors discovering exculpatory evidence (Korey's psychiatric diary showing history of self-injury), strongly implying Hall is innocent scapegoat. Career and reputation destroyed based on recanted confession from unreliable ex-boyfriend with criminal history.

quote_or_scene: Defense attorney: 'The fabric under the victim's nails doesn't match the suspect's coat.' Rodgers: 'The truck didn't kill him. He was already dead. Heart attack... He was shot.' Logan: 'I'll call CSU, tell them to start looking for a shell.'
notes: Arrested as initial suspect for pushing Renkmeyer into traffic. Cleared when autopsy revealed victim was shot before being hit by truck. Defense attorney got him released quickly when physical evidence (fabric) didn't match. No indication of public exposure beyond arrest, but transcript doesn't show what happened after release.

quote_or_scene: Stone: 'Officer, the charge is felony perjury. Take her to the 5th Precinct.' Schiff: 'And we do this to hardened criminals, not innocent bystanders.' Stone: 'If she lies, she's no longer innocent... But maybe a few nights in Rikers will change her mind.'
notes: Ann Madsen DID commit perjury (lied under oath about seeing Rostov), but her initial lie was driven by genuine fear of mob retaliation. Stone arrested her not because she was the primary subject of investigation, but as leverage to force her to testify truthfully against Steven Green. The harm (arrest, jail time in Rikers, public exposure in court) was a prosecutorial tactic rather than a legitimate criminal case against her as a primary offender. Stone himself acknowledges this is unusual ('we do this to hardened criminals, not innocent bystanders'). She is 'partially_involved' because she did lie under oath, but the accusation's severity (felony perjury arrest) was disproportionate and instrumentalized. Transcript is truncated during her testimony, so final resolution unknown.

quote_or_scene: MONTERO: 'Spotted him running across Broadway. Three Blaupunkts and a Delco in his bag.' JEROME: 'Yo, I didn't shoot nobody. There was no shot.' JEROME: 'Man, the lady was bagged when I got here.' Detective: 'Take him in.' JEROME: 'What's up?' Detective: 'For the radios.'
notes: Jerome was spotted running from the crime scene with stolen car radios. He was arrested but clearly states he didn't shoot anyone and says the woman was already shot when he arrived. Detectives acknowledge 'First the shooter, then this guy' indicating they know Jerome is a separate case. He was arrested only for the radio thefts, not the shooting. No indication of public exposure beyond the arrest itself - appears to be a straightforward theft arrest that happened to occur at a shooting scene.

police_conduct_quote: LOGAN: Robberies happen all the time. Now, maybe the detectives down at the Barrington let things slide, but we don't. We want the shooter, big guy. BRISCOE: I don't know, I... Good, we'll take you. You're just as good for it.
quote_or_scene: Detectives threaten to arrest Zabel: 'Good, we'll take you. You're just as good for it.' Zabel then admits his brother-in-law Charlie Kett was the actual robber. Later cleared when Kett is found to have been in Rikers during Hayashi murder.
tags: wrong_ID; coerced_confession; circumstantial_case; arrested; charges_dropped; public_confrontation
notes: Zabel worked at front desk where Hayashi cashed $10k in traveler's checks. Previously worked at Barrington hotel where similar robbery occurred. Admitted under pressure that brother-in-law Charlie Kett committed Barrington robbery and threatened him to help. Cleared when Kett found to be in Rikers on DWI at time of Hayashi murder.

police_conduct_quote: LOGAN: And meanwhile, the better part of 10 grand is falling out of his wallet. BRISCOE: I'm calling my lawyer. LOGAN: Good. Tell him to meet you at the station house.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Suzy about her criminal record: 'I just called up her yellows. Felony larceny, solicitation, and a little incident of you discharging a weapon. .22, surprise, surprise.' They arrest her and take her to station. Cleared when forensic evidence shows blonde pubic hair on victim's watch, but Suzy is brunette.
notes: Suzy admitted being with Hayashi and going to his room but denied having sex or killing him. Has prior record including weapons charge with .22 caliber gun. Arrested based on being last known person with victim and prior weapon possession. Cleared when forensic hair evidence proved different woman (blonde, not brunette) was in Hayashi's bed.

quote_or_scene: Sally (Laura's colleague): 'Is Victor Conner a suspect?' followed by detectives investigating him at Madsen Publishing where he maintains an office two floors below Laura's
notes: Conner was investigated due to prior domestic violence (911 tape shows him breaking into bathroom where Laura and Maggie were hiding), recent argument over custody papers worth 'six zeros,' and Laura's car found coming from Queens direction. Timeline shows he had alibi (limo to airport confirmed, flight to Boston). Investigation at his workplace (Madsen Publishing) constitutes public exposure to colleagues including Sally Kessler who discusses his history openly with detectives.

police_conduct_quote: BRISCOE: 'We tear your life apart, are we gonna find somebody in it with a hydraulic jack?' ... 'Let's go! Come on!' ... 'or you finish your recovery in an infirmary at Rikers. No private rooms there, Henry. No pretty nurses. The orderlies there'll slit your throat to steal your I.V.'
quote_or_scene: Henry is recovering in hospital from alcoholic cardiomyopathy after being handcuffed in vault by real burglars. Detectives aggressively interrogate him in hospital bed, threaten him with Rikers if he doesn't give up accomplices. He finally gives up his cousin Eddie under duress. Later Eddie is arrested and charged, but cooperates and reveals the real stolen property location, proving Eddie WAS guilty of the vault burglary.
notes: Henry was a victim of the vault burglary (jumped and handcuffed by real burglars). Detectives suspected him of being involved due to finding his whiskey bottle in basement and him lying about never going there. They threatened him in his hospital bed while recovering from serious heart condition. However, Henry then implicates his cousin Eddie, who turns out to be ACTUALLY GUILTY of the vault burglary. Henry himself appears innocent of the vault burglary but was coerced. The exposure was at his workplace (vault facility) and in hospital with manager present.

quote_or_scene: OLIVET: 'James Gordon had a form of mental retardation known as microencephaly. The frontal lobes of his brain never developed... He lacked the ability to perform higher order activities, such as logical reasoning and planning... was he capable of forming the requisite criminal intent to perform a criminal act as defined by the penal law? No.' MARJORIE: 'I gave him a dollar a week. He spent it on baseball cards... He must've sold them to get the money.' [for the bracelet engraved 'Guinevere']
tags: wrongful_shooting; murdered; media_outing; mentally_disabled; proven_innocent_posthumously; no_criminal_intent; legitimate_money_source; killed_by_police
notes: James Gordon is the clearest case of an innocent person killed due to false accusation. Expert testimony proves he lacked mental capacity to form criminal intent (IQ 40, microencephaly, kindergarten-level functioning). His presence at ATM was not criminal—he had legitimately earned money (sold baseball cards) to buy girlfriend's ID bracelet. He was unarmed. Van Buren shot him believing he was accomplice to armed robbery, but evidence shows: (1) he couldn't form intent to commit crime, (2) he had legitimate funds for the gift he wanted to buy, (3) girlfriend testified he 'wouldn't steal.' His mother lost her son; his reputation was publicly destroyed as 'robber.' Van Buren gives partial apology to mother at end, acknowledging 'I killed him... and I will never live a day without that tearing me up.' Consequence severity = 4 (death). Public exposure through investigation, media coverage of shooting, grand jury proceedings.

police_conduct_quote: A witness puts you in the park this morning. [...] I know what this is about. It's that kid, the one on TV? [...] Kids are not my thing.
quote_or_scene: BRISCOE: 'A witness puts you in the park this morning.' ROBERT: 'I know what this is about. It's that kid, the one on TV?' [...] He has the girl's name, number, everything. He's in the clear as far as this case goes.
notes: Robert was identified by a Guatemalan nanny as a 'bald man' taking pictures of kids in the playground around the time of the kidnapping. He was brought in for questioning, and detectives found a diaper in his possession, creating suspicion. However, he was quickly cleared when his alibi and his contact list of nannies proved he was a 'commercials agent' using a pickup line to meet lonely nannies. No public exposure beyond police interrogation. Logan states 'He's in the clear as far as this case goes.' The real crime (smothering) occurred at home, not in the park. Severity is 1 because questioning was private with no public exposure or formal charges.

police_conduct_quote: LOGAN: 'Give me your cuffs, Lennie.' / BRISCOE: 'In the meantime, you're under arrest for the rape of Lyssa Wesley.'
quote_or_scene: Locke arrested for rape but cooperates and reveals Talbert as perpetrator. DA offers plea: 'Cooperate and the charge is leaving the scene of an accident. Six months' probation.'
notes: Locke was driving Lyssa home after Talbert allegedly raped her. Detectives initially suspect him of rape due to his presence at scene. He's arrested and threatened with multiple felonies before cooperating. Ultimately charged only with leaving scene of accident.

quote_or_scene: SARAH: 'Now the press is all over my office. They're in the lobby of my apartment. I can't live like this, Miss Kincaid.' / McCoy threatens her: 'The case against Talbert is dropped, Miss Maslin. The case against you for conspiracy is just beginning.'
tags: media_outing; prosecutorial_overreach; fabricated_claim; lawyer; witness_recant; reputation_destroyed
notes: Sarah initially claims Talbert raped her, then recants when facing public exposure. Prosecution accuses her of lying/political motivation ('conspiracy'). Ultimately proven she told truth about coerced sex (quid pro quo harassment, not forcible rape). Press exposes her, career threatened by having to testify about 'sleeping her way to partnership.' McCoy's threat of conspiracy charges was baseless intimidation—she was actually a victim of different crime (extortion/coercion).

quote_or_scene: BRISCOE: 'Yeah, well, Piselli fits the bill. He wears glasses and he's mad.' Later: 'Check his alibi first.' Detectives visit him at his business (Cleans and Dirties product), question him publicly. Alice Huntley testifies: 'Did the police indicate to you they had a suspect in the murder? Yes. Carl Piselli. Not John Curren? No. They didn't mention him.'
notes: Piselli was the primary suspect during initial investigation. Police questioned him at his business about inventing dishwasher magnets. He had motive (angry at Kopinsky), threatened Kopinsky and Alice Huntley, wore glasses matching witness description. Cleared by solid alibi (Hudson Jazz Orchestra concert with witnesses). Alice Huntley's trial testimony confirms police identified him as their suspect to her, not Curren. Public questioning at his business constitutes exposure even though he was ultimately cleared quickly via alibi.

police_conduct_quote: BRISCOE: 'Come on, Johnny. You found out Kopinsky was fleecing your mother after he had already fleeced you, and you got mad! Hell, I would've gotten mad.' LOGAN: 'So you went downtown to get your mother's money back. What happened? Did Kopinsky stall you? No. Did he laugh at you? No.' BRISCOE: 'I give up. What happened?' When Curren asks for lawyer: 'VAN BUREN: John Curren, you're under arrest for the murder of Arthur Kopinsky.'
quote_or_scene: Lineup identification by Tanaka ('I'd think number four'). Arrested in front of wife and children at home. Trial testimony reveals Tappan manipulated him: 'He said he'd pay us back, my mother and me. Every cent, if I killed Kopinsky.' Prosecution offers manslaughter deal (8.33 years) in exchange for testimony against Tappan, the true architect of the murder.
tags: defendant; public_trial; arrested; perp_walk; coerced_confession; blue_collar; murder_case; family_destroyed
notes: PARTIALLY_INVOLVED: Curren actually committed the murder (pulled trigger), BUT was manipulated into doing so by Tappan, who orchestrated the killing to end Kopinsky's blackmail. Curren is a victim of Tappan's fraud (lost $830K lifesavings) who was weaponized by Tappan. The episode reveals the true architect was Tappan. Curren suffered: arrest in front of family, $100K bail he couldn't afford, public trial, coercive police interrogation. Eventually accepts manslaughter plea (8.33 years) to testify against Tappan. His harm stems from being falsely positioned as the sole responsible party when Tappan bears primary moral/legal responsibility. Including because the show's resolution treats Tappan as the real murderer ('evincing depraved indifference') and Curren as a manipulated tool.

Colin appears to be the actual shooter based on: (1) gunpowder residue on his gloves, (2) witness placing him with the gun 30 minutes before the murder, (3) his father's false confession to protect him contains factual errors proving father didn't do it, (4) Stewart Barclay's father negotiating for his son's testimony implicating Colin. Case dismissed on suppression of evidence (illegal search), not innocence. Father later confesses to protect him. Not counted as falsely accused because he actually committed the crime.

notes: Tom Harrigan falsely confessed to murder to protect his son Colin (the actual shooter). He pled guilty, waived indictment, negotiated 15-to-life sentence, and appeared at allocution hearing (public courtroom). His confession contained a critical factual error: he said he 'waited for the car to drive away' but the driver had dropped Prescott half a block away, proving Tom didn't witness the scene. McCoy caught this during allocution and moved for continuance. Tom was arrested, read Miranda rights on-screen, and taken into custody. His partial thumbprint on the gun likely from helping dispose of it. This is a life-altering consequence (severity 4) - he was willing to spend 15 years to life in prison for a murder he didn't commit. Public exposure through courtroom allocution and arrest.

The 'accusation' here was of patronizing prostitutes, which he was actually doing, but the PUBLIC HARM from the false murder investigation exposure justifies inclusion. His coerced, unreliable testimony was central to both suspect theories.

tags: wrongful_conviction; prosecutorial_overreach; media_outing; public_trial; jailed_pretrial; reputation_destroyed; murder_case; fabricated_claim; witness_recant
notes: Dillard was convicted of serial murders of 5 black boys based on circumstantial evidence (fiber matches, handwriting analysis, racist motive). Served 5 years in prison in protective custody. Real killer Simon Brooks confessed to all murders. Evidence of prosecutorial misconduct: concealed witness statement identifying Brooks with victim #3, and suborned perjury from handwriting expert who initially couldn't match the notes. City settled Dillard's $50M lawsuit for $3M. Conviction was based on: fibers matching delivery uniform, handwriting 'match' to notes, being seen arguing with victim, and racist background (he'd been mugged by black youth). All circumstantial. Episode reveals ADA Diana Hawthorne deliberately concealed exculpatory evidence and pressured expert to change testimony.

Detectives pressure her for fingerprints to compare to crime scene. She refuses, invoking Mark Fuhrman (OJ Simpson case reference). Case moves away from her.
notes: Arlene is Charley's ex-girlfriend, witnessed arguing with him publicly days before murder. Becomes initial suspect but alibi is corroborated. Detectives use coercive language and pressure for fingerprints. However, exposure remains police-only with no indication it spread beyond the interrogation. No evidence of work/family/community finding out. Consequence_severity=1 because while she experienced intimidating interrogation, there's no public exposure or material harm. Does not meet threshold for inclusion in harm count (police_only + severity 1 = exclude from final dataset per rubric).

quote_or_scene: FLYNN: I then enlisted Detective Briscoe to remove the evidence against that individual from the property room. And Detective Briscoe did as you instructed? Yes. Detective Briscoe took the drugs. I know because he gave me half.
notes: Flynn knowingly lies under oath to the Hellman Commission to implicate Briscoe in a 5-year-old evidence theft actually committed by deceased Officer Dave Spence. Briscoe testifies publicly that he was drunk/asleep at home (exposing his alcoholism). His career is threatened until Officer Betty Abrams provides alibi testimony (revealing their affair). The actual consequence severity involves public humiliation before a high-profile corruption commission, exposure of personal failings (alcoholism, affair), and career jeopardy. Transcript cuts off before resolution but Officer Abrams' testimony appears to exonerate him.

quote_or_scene: FLYNN: When he heard that Ruben Morales had turned state's evidence, he wanted him eliminated. Killed. Yes, sir. [...] The individual threatened to harm my family. I informed Detective Edwards as to the situation. We decided, out of concern for our families, that we had no other option but to participate.
notes: Morales was a drug dealer who made a cooperation deal with the DA to testify against his boss Hector Garcia in exchange for witness protection. Flynn set up a fake drug buy and killed Morales, claiming self-defense (that Morales reached for a gun). While Morales was guilty of drug dealing, he was innocent of the accusation that triggered his death: attempting to rob/attack the officers during the buy. The 'accusation' was the false claim of self-defense used to justify the hit. Brother Richie confirms Ruben was cooperating and 'getting out.' The harm (murder) flows directly from Flynn's need to create a pretext. Including because the false accusation (rip-off attempt) was the mechanism for a contract killing of a cooperating witness.

Released after defense attorney challenged probable cause. Exposure limited to police station - no evidence of workplace/family/media exposure.

Judge found she acted as government agent and manufactured the crime. Final evidence strongly suggests Roney herself committed the shooting using Tate's car (which she had secret keys to). Tate was arrested publicly, indicted, and went through public hearing before dismissal. His bail was posted by Books himself in a public show. Charges dismissed on entrapment grounds, strongly implying innocence of the actual shooting.

Detectives questioned him with implicit threats about his construction business connections. His alibi was verified by bartender at Cardi's. Questioning remained police-only with no public exposure beyond those present at the restaurant argument (which predated the shooting and was unrelated to police accusation).

Police conducted aggressive interrogation including taking him to morgue. Cleared when investigation revealed actual perpetrator (Flores working for Russo). No formal charges filed, but subjected to hostile questioning. Exposure limited to police interaction - no public accusation detected in transcript.

notes: Father accused after argument with Triandos at party over stolen laptop. Son ultimately reveals father stole fur coat but returned it. Interrogation uses son against father but exposure appears limited to police station. No indication of public exposure beyond this, so severity 2 (interrogation tactics) rather than higher.

Was alone in house during murder (passed out drunk). Though initially questioned by police as potential suspect, the major public accusation comes at trial. He's fired by Kim post-murder. Publicly accused in courtroom of murder for money, which is severe reputational harm even without conviction.

Detectives confront her publicly in front of employer. Alibi with 10 coworkers clears her. Was victim of Keene's sexual blackmail but not involved in murder.

And: 'I'm not going to dazzle you with a lot of bull, Miss Ross. Evan and I are realistic about our chances with a jury. You put a serious offer on the table, we'll give it a good, hard look.' Grant also mentions: 'Money's all gone. My friends in LA stopped returning my calls.'

The prosecution later pivots to Newman as the true suspect. Ross is clearly investigating Newman while Grant remains under charges, strongly implying Grant is not the actual perpetrator. The episode's title 'Turnaround' and the investigation's shift away from Grant indicate he is innocent. Public exposure occurred through arrest and legal proceedings (courtroom). Financial and social consequences are evident.

He spent 3 days in jail before Garcia confessed. The arrest destroyed his wedding day—a life milestone that cannot be recovered. His father-in-law's initial quote 'You ruined my wedding for nothing' captures the irreversible harm. Later threatened by Garcia's brother to prevent testimony. Blood evidence (Sherman's type AB on his jacket) was explained as transfer during tire change assistance, not murder. Bodak had lied initially about leaving work at 9am (actually 6am) and about Saudi prince tip because he was moonlighting for a bookie and feared exposure to his cop father-in-law. This deception made him seem guilty but was unrelated to the murder.

CURTIS: Joni Timberman was kicking your ass at your job, and you couldn't take it. The only way you could justify losing out to her was to make up that story about her seducing your writers.

Detectives used coercive tactics accusing him of fabricating affair story and being unable to compete professionally. He was cleared when his assistant confirmed victim visited his office Saturday and left alive, and when focus shifted to Posner then Evans. No indication interrogation became public beyond police station.

notes: Burke questioned aggressively at recording studio in front of colleagues/producer. Failed to show for 2pm session, arrived 4pm, creating 2-hour window. Police threatened him during interrogation. Blood test definitively excluded him (type mismatch). No indication of apology from detectives.

So, unless somebody else falls out of your family tree... You're it.' Douglas responds: 'I cannot believe this. It's not my blood. I think I better get a lawyer.'
notes: DNA analysis showed victim's blood (type B) and perpetrator's blood (type O) shared common allele indicating family relationship. Douglas was victim's only known blood relative, making him prime suspect. Subjected to aggressive interrogation with insults and threats. Ultimately cleared when sister Sonja Harland (previously unknown biological daughter) identified as true perpetrator. Exposure limited to police interrogation room - no public exposure documented in transcript.

quote_or_scene: CURTIS: 'Six people in the second group. Who's the target?' BRISCOE: 'Well, the dead guy's a good place to start.' Later revealed: 'The bullet went through Susan Beckner into him.' CURTIS: 'So if the shooter was actually aiming, Wexman wasn't the target. She was.'
notes: Wexman was initially investigated as the primary target of the shooting because he was killed. However, ballistics later proved the bullet passed through Susan Beckner into him, making him an innocent bystander. He was using the alias Larry Rice to attend singles events while married. His death was a consequence of being in the wrong place, not of being accused, so while he qualifies as proven innocent, the harm (death) was not from the accusation itself but from the shooting. Including as context but noting the harm preceded/was independent of any accusation.

notes: Warren Talbert is a 48-year-old architect who admits to burying the baby but claims it was already dead from natural causes. The M.E. confirms strangulation, contradicting his account. McCoy threatens to indict him as co-conspirator and has him arrested for contempt when he refuses to testify. His wife testifies he confessed to finding the baby alive. Defense argues he may have killed it himself. While he confessed to burial (a crime), he is innocent of the murder accusation - the baby was already dead when he found it according to his account, and the show strongly implies the students killed it (they wrapped it in a towel and hid it under newspaper in a trash can). His jailing for contempt and public courtroom exposure of the murder theory constitute significant harm.

He's treated as prime suspect initially due to his abusive behavior toward models and recent work with victim. Cleared when alibi (Europe travel receipts) confirmed and witnesses indicate nothing happened during fittings. Public questioning in front of employees/models = severity 2.

notes: EXTREMELY HIGH HARM CASE. Ramirez publicly identified on TV news by victims' lawyer Drake, with full name, mug shot from prior arrest, allegation he 'raped and ultimately killed' victim, statement police 'let him slip through their fingers,' and $250,000 bounty on his head. This creates massive media frenzy and public manhunt. Mother describes him as 'good boy' who 'respected Brittany' and wanted to 'save her' from exploitation. His concern for victim suggests protectiveness, not predation. Evidence against him: wearing Mets cap, seen near Baltimore house (his mother worked there), had 'always looked at Brittany' per housekeeper. No interview occurs, no physical evidence mentioned, but he's already convicted in court of public opinion with quarter-million-dollar bounty. Transcript ends with him still at large, meaning he's living as hunted fugitive based on thin circumstantial evidence. Severity 4: life-destroying media exposure with bounty, likely innocent based on mother's characterization and weak evidence base.

Prosecution theory was he killed wife to prevent exposure of being Black and having biracial baby. Career and reputation severely damaged despite innocence.

She begged me to reconsider. I said our mind was made up. I didn't know what to think after Karin died. I called Frances. She said Karin was dead and we had to protect our son. She told you your son killed your wife? No. No, not in so many words. But that's what I understood.'
