Frances Houston deliberately led Josh to believe David was responsible ('we had to protect our son'). No evidence David was publicly accused or that investigation focused on him beyond Josh's private fears. Appears to have been manipulated by his mother. No public exposure evident from transcript, so severity rated low despite family trauma.

quote_or_scene: Oscar Liriano, you're under arrest for the murder of Manny Ehrlich... This one's ours, fellas. / Judge: The defendant is remanded. May 1st. / Liriano: Everybody's gonna think I capped the guy.
tags: arrested; perp_walk; indicted; jailed_pretrial; public_trial; prosecutorial_overreach; wrongful_conviction
notes: Unique case: Liriano consented to a 'shadow prosecution' where he was knowingly charged with a murder he didn't commit as part of a sting operation to expose corruption. Despite his consent, he suffered real public exposure (arrest in front of girlfriend, public court appearances, remanded to Rikers for up to 3 months) and reputation damage ('Everybody's gonna think I capped the guy'). The prosecution was real in its public effects even though internally known to be false. He was also accused of the underlying drug case, where his innocence is not established, but the murder accusation qualifies him for inclusion.

quote_or_scene: Fire investigator report states 'Father recovered. Kid didn't' and 'Says here it started three feet from the couch... After he came to. He was out when they found him... his blood alcohol was .25. He was loaded.' Later revealed Terry set the fire, not Roy.
notes: Roy Lawlor was blamed for his daughter's death for two years. The arson squad closed the case attributing the fire to his negligence (drunk, cigarette). He carried this guilt publicly until detectives discovered evidence pointing to his son Terry. His employer and colleagues were aware of his involvement. The transcript shows he was questioned at work by detectives in front of his boss about the answering machine message, indicating workplace exposure of the original accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Briscoe: 'Well, look at the bright side, Stan, you're not wearing handcuffs.' Curtis threatens to take him from work with police.
quote_or_scene: At lumber store on West 88th. Detectives question him about Dee-Dee murder confession. Boss present. 'And I'm leaving with two cops?' Briscoe: 'Well, look at the bright side, Stan, you're not wearing handcuffs.' Later: 'Listen, send Mr. Kaminski home' after Dina Perucci found alive.
notes: Kaminski was publicly confronted at his workplace (lumber store) by detectives investigating a murder confession left on his answering machine. His employer was present during questioning. He was escorted from work by police and held briefly before being cleared when the actual intended recipient of the call (Roy Lawlor) was identified. The message was meant for the previous owner of his phone number.

quote_or_scene: Forensics: 'The swab on that slide came from the bathroom counter in Nasser's hotel room... Sodium bicarbonate can also be used as a stabilizing agent. Home-made explosives?' Van Buren: 'I'll alert ATF.' Later: Rodriguez arrests Nasser at Battery Park. Nasser: 'I'm an Egyptian citizen! What's in the bag? Medical equipment.'
notes: Nasser was detained based on sodium bicarbonate residue suggesting bomb-making materials. He was arrested at Battery Park carrying medical equipment. He is later revealed to be an OB/GYN brought to NYC to perform FGM, not a terrorist. He was held by INS for visa violations after terrorism suspicion was cleared. The terrorism accusation itself was proven false; his actual crime (conspiracy to perform illegal FGM) is separate.

Why don't you write it down for us?'
notes: Patel was accused by the victim's sister of killing Moussad for money. She was questioned by detectives and provided an alibi. Investigation shifted to Eric Martin after evidence pointed elsewhere. No indication of public exposure beyond police questioning.

police_conduct_quote: Lennie: 'Your kid's lying?' Curtis: 'So your kid's lying?' to Eric Martin, implying Nari's guilt based on daughter's initial statement.

Detectives questioned both Nari and her husband, with exposure to family members present. Alison later recanted and identified her father Eric as the one who left. LARRY: At home with my wife, my kids and my mother. She's staying with us during the trial. [...] CURTIS: Big break he won't be able to testify, huh? It's funny how things work out, huh? notes: Larry, brother of Worley's victim Lisa, had attacked Worley at arraignment. Detectives questioned him as suspect due to motive (preventing Mayer's testimony that could free Worley). Provided alibi with wife, kids, and mother. Cleared when Carson identified. Questioning occurred in front of family members present during trial.

He is cleared when the actual serial killer Eddie Chandler is identified. Public questioning about a murder accusation constitutes severity 2 harm through social exposure.

quote_or_scene: GIDAMAL: Broken nose, three fractured ribs, severe concussion... He sustained some bruises and lacerations earlier this week. CURTIS: The Russos said their sister accused Harding. They lied about that.

The Russo brothers beat him based on Leslie's false accusation (she actually had consensual relations with Roger). The harm - near-fatal beating - was consequence of FALSE accusation re: Leslie Russo. Include because harm from false accusation clearly outweighs his actual guilt in separate crime.

notes: Baxter was beaten by the Russo brothers who mistakenly believed he raped their sister. He told them it wasn't him and pointed to Harding. The beating is public harm (physical violence) caused by false accusation. He was never the actual rapist of Leslie Russo.

His girlfriend Vicky Grant was the actual shooter.

person_label: Leonard Gardner (homeless man claiming to be Pope Adrian VI)
quote_or_scene: WOMAN: His prints are in the system. Leonard Gardner. Multiples for trespassing, vagrancy, petty theft. He spent the night of the murder in the 16 for urinating on a public street. Was released the next day. The times check out? I called over. He was grabbed up at 7:30.
notes: Leonard Gardner is a mentally ill homeless man with delusions of being Pope Adrian VI. He had Dr. Burk's hat (which he gave her as protection) and was initially pursued as a suspect. He is definitively cleared by being in police custody (arrested for public urination at 7:30pm, night of murder) with verified alibi. However, there is no indication his accusation became public beyond police investigation - no media, workplace, family exposure documented. While he was arrested, this was for a separate offense (public urination) not the murder accusation. The murder suspicion appears contained to the detective squad. Given strict rubric requiring PUBLIC exposure or physical harm as consequence OF THE ACCUSATION, this case is borderline. Including because: (1) he was actively pursued/interrogated as murder suspect, (2) he was already in custody which extended his detention, (3) mentally vulnerable population. However, could argue for exclusion due to no documented public exposure of murder accusation.

quote_or_scene: BILLY: 'I got there late, and I was just taking off my coat when Louis pulled me into May's bedroom. And he had this gun... And [May] was hysterical. She was telling us how she got this letter, and that she had AIDS... She told me to put down the gun, and she picked it up, and somehow it went off. I thought I killed her.' Witness Louis Morse confirms. Transcript shows: 'We've got the kid's statement. Confirmation from the witness? Yes. He saw the fight.' McCoy: 'I talked to Billy's lawyer... It sounds like it happened the way he said. Freaked out, the gun went off. I'm inclined to make the deal.'
notes: Billy was accused based on being present at scene with gun and May's death. His confession describes an accident during May's emotional crisis about her AIDS diagnosis. Witness Louis Morse corroborates the struggle. Prosecution accepts his account and makes a deal (implied plea to lesser charge or dismissal). No indication of public exposure beyond police interrogation. Excluded from count due to police_only exposure with no clear material harm beyond arrest/interrogation. The deal suggests charges were substantially reduced or dropped. Consequence severity 3 for arrest but exposure remained contained.

Max explains he brought the gun, someone took it from his pocket. Alibi witness Gloria confirms: 'I came up in the elevator with him... he pretty much kept an eye on me the whole night.' Max charged with criminal possession of weapon but cleared of involvement in May's death.

Alibi witness Gloria confirms he was with her entire time at party. Transcript shows he was 'booked for criminal possession of the weapon' but cleared of murder. Exposure appears limited to police interrogation. Excluded from count: while arrested (severity 3), exposure channel was police_only with no evidence of public/workplace/family exposure. The gun possession charge is separate from the false murder accusation.

Police arrested him for disseminating indecent material and harassment while investigating Blake's murder. He was in Rikers at time of murder, proving innocence. He was later kidnapped from Queens wholesaler and murdered by the actual killer Matthew Odell. Severity 4 due to being murdered as consequence of investigation making him visible/vulnerable to the actual perpetrator.

LOIS: 'No, it can't be. That's impossible.'

You couldn't stand sleeping next to a guy who'd turned your son into a potted plant.' She breaks down and reveals she left Michael with daughter Stephanie, shifting suspicion.
notes: Lois was having an affair with dance instructor Gilbert during time of murder (3:30-4:40pm), giving her an alibi. Detectives used aggressive tactics including showing M.E. report and accusing her of murder. She broke under pressure and blamed her daughter. Exposure was to family (daughter and husband learned of affair and accusation). No formal charges filed once alibi confirmed, but suffered family rupture and public confrontation.

Then: 'You just have to tell us what happened. I mean, your brother was barely living anyway, right?' BRISCOE: 'Your mom's a better liar than you are, Stephanie.'

Were you jealous of all the attention he got?' Stephanie denies, provides alibi with friend Kara at Asteroid Palace arcade from 3:15-4:15, confirmed by witnesses.
notes: Accused by her own mother under police pressure. Detectives used coercive tactics suggesting brother 'was barely living anyway.' Alibi confirmed by friend and arcade workers. Exposure limited to interrogation room with detectives—no indication it spread to school, media, or broader community beyond family knowing mother blamed her.

police_conduct_quote: CURTIS to Joe: 'You see your boy, he used to be strong. Played soccer, yeah? ... Did you imagine Michael at 20 years old? Forty years old? Still in that same room, same bed, same tortured pain? ... Someone you love is suffering. They have no hope. What can you do to help this person? ... You had to do it. You had to do it because you loved him. Let it go. It was an act of love, Joe.'
quote_or_scene: Detective Curtis uses empathy-based coercion comparing Joe's situation to his own wife's MS, saying 'It was an act of love, Joe. I loved Michael.' Joe responds 'I didn't do this. I didn't kill him.' Arrested anyway. Case goes to trial with bail set at $100,000 (posted by employer Cashman). Trial testimony shows Semenko was the killer. Charges eventually dropped when Semenko arrested.

notes: Strongest case: arrested, $100K bail, went to public trial as defendant. Evidence: worked on Southern State Parkway where hemlock grows wild, witness (Mrs. Bing) saw him spike food with 'cinnamon,' employer (Cashman) initially told police Joe wished he'd never saved Michael (later recanted). Endured coercive interrogation, public arrest, trial with cross-examination revealing affair and family dysfunction. Wife's affair exposed in trial. Employer posted bail showing support. Prosecution dropped case when Dr. Semenko arrested with hemlock in his car. Suffered massive financial (legal fees, lost work time), reputational (publicly accused of murdering disabled son), and family (wife's affair exposed, marriage strained) harm.

He suffered life-threatening gunshot wound requiring hospitalization, critical condition, and post-traumatic amnesia. Mayor awards him medal after truth emerges. Physical harm (shot in head, nearly died) directly resulted from being misidentified as the attacker in the moment of the crime.

She accidentally hit the teacher. She's innocent of attempted murder of the teacher specifically - this was collateral damage while defending herself. DA eventually offers minimal sentence (1 year juvenile detention) acknowledging the mitigating circumstances. The teacher herself 'asked us not to land on the girl with both feet.'

He did commit harassment but is 'innocent' of manslaughter/murder. However, he was later murdered, making his exposure/consequences from the Abbott case investigation significant. The courtroom exposure is public record.

ROSS: 'Her whereabouts are unaccounted for and she had access to the same caliber weapon that killed Marco. And she had a motive.' Father present during interrogation; threat of arrest used as leverage.

While contained to the interrogation room (not public media exposure), the threat of arrest in front of her father and the coercive tactics constitute harm. She had prior suicide attempt history mentioned by her aunt, making the interrogation particularly concerning. Severity 2: public confrontation with authority figure threatening arrest.

notes: Stokes was beaten by a mob before police arrival, then arrested based on two witness IDs (drug dealer Calvin Berry and security guard who sketched him). He was publicly arrested, indicted, and case was advancing to trial before DA discovered evidence pointing to Castillo. Judge Feldman dismissed indictment and apologized. Stokes has prior conviction for loitering near schoolyard and was taking Depo Provera (sex offender treatment drug), making him vulnerable target. Violence from mob + coerced confession + public indictment = severity 4.

police_conduct_quote: Officers treat Nicholas gently during arrest despite his distress.
quote_or_scene: CURTIS: 'We have to arrest him.' [Later] SKODA describes Nicholas confessing to hitting the baby. M.E. later reveals: 'that little girl was dead by the time her brother laid a hand on her.' CARMICHAEL to parents: 'It's a relief to know Nicholas didn't kill her.'
tags: wrongful_arrest; child_suspect; public_confrontation; institutionalized; psychological_harm; family_separation; proven_innocent_by_autopsy
notes: Nicholas is a 7-year-old with severe attachment disorder and history of abuse. He confessed to attacking the baby postmortem (not knowing she was already dead). ADA Carmichael had him arrested and removed from parents' custody, placing him in Bellevue psychiatric lockup. Parents witnessed arrest and begged for him to come home. M.E.'s autopsy proved baby died of heart failure before Nicholas touched her. While Nicholas has severe behavioral issues, the murder accusation was false. Parents were removed as guardians through legal maneuvering before the arrest. The arrest scene shows Nicholas being taken away while parents plead. Carmichael acknowledges relief he didn't kill the baby but no formal apology shown in transcript. Severity 4 due to arrest of a 7-year-old, institutionalization, and family separation—all life-altering for a child.

person_label: Elizabeth and Phillip Waring (Nicholas's adoptive parents)
police_conduct_quote: BRISCOE: 'Are we under arrest?' CURTIS: 'Not at the moment.' [Implying potential arrest] Later: 'Then you can come to the station with us.'
quote_or_scene: Elizabeth Waring: 'I can't believe you think we would hurt her. You think we spent five years on a waiting list just so we could beat a baby to death three days after we brought her home?' Detectives demand entry to apartment. Later, ADA Carmichael has court remove them as Nicholas's guardians so psychiatrist can interview him. Mrs. Waring: 'You people look at him and you see a little monster. My husband and I see a wonderful boy who has suffered horrors.'
tags: initial_suspect; public_confrontation; threatened_arrest; parental_rights_removed; child_removed; reputation_damage; wrongful_accusation
notes: The Warings were initially suspected of killing the baby they had just adopted. Detectives publicly confronted them, demanded apartment access, threatened station house questioning. When they refused entry, detectives obtained warrant. ADA Carmichael later used family court to remove them as Nicholas's guardians, arguing they were abusive/neglectful based on Nicholas's locked room—this was actually recommended therapy for his attachment disorder. The guardianship removal allowed psychiatrist access to Nicholas, leading to his arrest. Parents witnessed their son being arrested and taken away. Baby's death was later proven to be from pre-existing medical conditions, not abuse by the Warings. Carmichael acknowledges Nicholas didn't kill the baby but no apology to parents shown. The transcript shows sustained suspicion and legal actions against loving parents trying to care for extremely difficult children. Severity 3: formal legal action (guardianship removal), child removal, public accusation, but not imprisonment.

police_conduct_quote: EDDIE: 'Rivera singled me out because I wouldn't work for him... Informing, right? I told him he could stick it and then he passed me off to his partner and now here I sit.'
quote_or_scene: EDDIE: 'Whole thing was a hook, man. I wasn't doing nothing but holding and they get me for intent to sell? It's a total hook... Detective Rivera framed you? Yeah, he singled me out because I wouldn't work for him.'
notes: Eddie claims Rivera framed him with intent-to-sell charges for refusing to inform. He's doing time at Crossroads juvenile facility. Tagged as partially_involved because he admits to 'holding' (possession) but claims the elevated charge (intent to sell) was retaliation for refusing to become an informant. Whoever wrote it called her a stank ass bitch.' / ED: 'We want you to write it for us.' / EVAN: 'Look, I was just letting go of my anger from being in there so long.' / ED: 'Is this guy a friend of yours?' [showing Morris photo] / EVAN: 'Does he look like a friend of mine?' / EVAN: 'But why I'm gonna kill her? My lawyer beat the case on a speedy trial motion. Ain't nothing she can do to me now.'
notes: Bruce wrote threatening note to Judge Karlin from jail but his case was already dismissed on speedy trial motion. Detectives threaten prosecution for the threatening note itself. Cleared when they find actual shooter Morris. No public exposure - interrogation stayed with police.

police_conduct_quote: ED: 'They found your gun in the shooter's hand.' / BRISCOE: 'You heard about this judge who got shot at in the city? One where the shooter got killed? What about it? They found your gun in the shooter's hand.' / ED: 'Who is it? You know, we could charge you right now as an accomplice, Mr. Ellis.'
quote_or_scene: Gun registry traces to Ellis. Detectives confront him at work. BRISCOE: 'You Vince Ellis?' ELLIS: 'Far as I know.' ED: 'We got your name off the state handgun registry. You bought a .38 about a year ago?' ELLIS: 'Yeah, but I don't got it no more. It was stolen.' / Later identifies nephew Frank Morris as thief: 'It's my nephew, Frankie. Frank Morris. Asked if he could use my .38. Said he'd give me 200 just to borrow it. I told him no way. Next night I come in and it's gone.'
notes: Gun traced to Ellis through state registry. Detectives confront him at his workplace, threaten accomplice charges. Cleared when he identifies nephew Morris as the one who stole gun. Public exposure at work when detectives questioned him there about murder weapon.

quote_or_scene: BRISCOE: How'd you find out we were looking for you? / Uh, on TV. That bag lady. / I was parked on the corner, like she said. / And you got into the car and... / It was a tight spot, you know, and I just got the car. So I'm trying to pull out, and I guess I was going kind of slow or something.
notes: Simon came in voluntarily after seeing himself described on TV. Detectives quickly cleared him when they realized the shooter was on the victim's left side, not right where Simon was parked. No public exposure beyond the police interview.

police_conduct_quote: BRISCOE: Where were you Monday morning, Mr. Krasner? / Teaching at PS 124, and I have 30 ten-year-olds who can vouch for me. / Where was your car? / On the street. / Mr. Krasner, is it possible that your wife was seeing someone else?
quote_or_scene: The husband drives a green mid-size sedan. / Yeah, and the shooter really wanted her dead. He used a dum-dum bullet. / Maybe we should round those bases again.
notes: Detectives pursued the husband as a suspect based on: (1) his green car matching witness description, (2) the professional nature of the hit (Black Talon bullets suggesting premeditation), and (3) marital disagreements mentioned. He was questioned about his whereabouts and possible marital infidelity. Though confined to police interaction, the questions about affairs and the implicit accusation constitute exposure with severity 2.

police_conduct_quote: ED: Then how come you hit her up for seven grand? / It was business. / Did you, uh, ever throw Martha any connections downtown in Tribeca?
quote_or_scene: JEFF: It was a dynamite business plan. / What was your role in this dot-com? / I gave her an office, got her some meetings, helped with the first round of financing... / And, uh, who gets the rights to this dynamite business plan now that Martha's dead? / Guys, I don't need to shoot people to get rich. I'm already rich.
notes: Waites was investigated as a suspect due to: (1) business partnership that went sour, (2) $7,000 payment from victim shortly before death, and (3) potential inheritance of business rights. Detectives employed aggressive questioning implying he might have killed her for the business. The direct accusatory questioning ('who gets the rights now that Martha's dead?') constitutes severity 2 exposure even though confined to police.

police_conduct_quote: We think your car may have been involved in a homicide. Now, if you have any idea who might have stolen it, please tell us.
quote_or_scene: MENDEL: Nice they send you all the way from Manhattan. That where they found it? / Yeah, it was seen there two days ago. / What do you mean, seen? Seen by who? / Why don't you just start by telling us where it was stolen from?
notes: Rabbi Mendel owned the green Buick Skylark used in the murder. He reported it stolen and was questioned when it was connected to the homicide. While technically not accused of the murder itself, the detectives' visit and questions about the car being involved in a homicide put him in an uncomfortable position. Severity 1 as it remained private with no formal accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Jimmy Clark: 'Somebody snatched your kid. Now, you make us believe you had nothing to do with it.' Context: Detectives chased him down at work, tackled him publicly ('Get up, get up, get up'), then interrogated him aggressively about his daughter's kidnapping.
quote_or_scene: GREEN: 'Two o'clock today, where were you?' JIMMY: 'Right here. Been working since noon.' GREEN: 'Your boss will vouch for that?' JIMMY: 'Check my timecard.' GREEN: 'Do you know why we're here?' JIMMY: 'The drunk driving warrant. I skipped my court date, right?' GREEN: 'Oh, man, you're not even close. We're here about your daughter.' JIMMY: 'Oh, come on, I'm gonna pay her the money. Denise is pissed she missed a sale at Filene's.' GREEN shows photo. FONTANA: 'She was abducted four hours ago. Somebody snatched your kid. Now, you make us believe you had nothing to do with it.' JIMMY: 'What? No way. Denise says you two have been having issues.' JIMMY: 'I would never do something like this.' GREEN: 'She's been hassling you for money!' JIMMY: 'Look man, I'm just short on cash. Where's my kid? What happened?'
tags: wrong_ID; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; circumstantial_case; blue_collar; family_member
notes: Jimmy Clark was behind on child support and had been denied visitation by his ex-wife Denise. Detectives suspected him based on custody dispute and financial motive. He was chased down and tackled at his construction site workplace in front of colleagues, then aggressively interrogated. His timecard and boss confirmed his alibi. The detectives' assessment afterward: 'A deadbeat, but we don't think he snatched the kid.' No apology shown. Exposure was public (coworkers witnessed the takedown) and the interrogation was coercive, qualifying as severity 2.

quote_or_scene: April testifies in court: 'Patrick Sullivan and I were lovers... It was consensual. It was always consensual... She killed Patrick out of jealousy... She's my mother. What was I supposed to do?' Then later: 'I told them you confessed to me about murdering the baby... When I testify, the jury's going to love it.'
notes: Lorraine is convicted of murdering Patrick Sullivan. However, the episode strongly suggests April actually killed Sullivan or was the primary actor. April manipulates the trial, first supporting her mother's self-defense claim (molestation story), then flipping to accuse Lorraine of jealousy killing. In the final scene, April's willingness to testify against Lorraine regarding the baby murder (which April actually committed) reveals her pattern of manipulation. Lorraine's statement 'You've got the wrong one' and April's demonstration of her capacity for murderous deception both point to Lorraine being wrongly convicted. The episode ends with April getting a deal by falsely implicating Lorraine in the baby's death, showing she'll sacrifice her mother repeatedly.

person_label: Rob Dolan (father of victim Sara Dolan)
quote_or_scene: DOLAN: 'Are you sure? After more than 10 years? You were trying to impede the investigation. Since you were the prime suspect.' ... 'I was. But that's not my fault.' HELLER: 'Really? Whose is it?' DOLAN: 'The lying, press hungry detectives in charge of the investigation.' ... DOLAN to McCoy: 'I come all the way down here, pick out the son of a bitch who killed Sara, and now you don't want me to testify?' ... 'my so-called friends continue to assume I raped and murdered my daughter.' ... DOLAN on stand: 'When that man strangled Sara, he murdered my daughter, my wife and me. I may still be breathing, but I've been dead for 10 years, three weeks and four days.'
tags: ruined_in_family; ruined_financially; media_outing; wrongful_suspicion_10_years; wife_died_from_stress; reputation_destroyed; wealthy; murder_case; CSA
notes: Dolan was never formally arrested or indicted, but was the 'prime suspect' for 10 years in his daughter's rape-murder. The case received massive media attention ('couldn't go five minutes without reading about her'). He hired a lawyer immediately, which detectives interpreted as guilt. He was publicly suspected by police, press, and community. His wife Amy died the day after Zona's indictment (heavily implied to be stress/grief-related from the decade of suspicion). Dolan describes himself as 'dead for 10 years' due to the accusation. McCoy offers partial apology by saying 'I'd like to say that I'm really sorry' at end. Fontana's final scene shows regret/discomfort, suggesting partial acknowledgment. Severity 4 due to wife's death, decade-long destroyed reputation, and life-altering consequences of being publicly suspected of murdering and raping his own child.

police_conduct_quote: Girl, you racked up quite a record before you were 18. Maybe now you're trying to turn things around. But I'm going to tell you, you go down for a conspiracy murder charge, you won't hold your son again until he's 28.
quote_or_scene: Detectives threaten her with conspiracy murder charges during interrogation. Later dialogue reveals she panicked and called Diablo (not Beto) when she learned Teresa was a journalist, but no charges are filed. DA later says 'We don't even have enough to prosecute her.'
notes: Lola was interrogated under threat of losing her son to Child Services and facing conspiracy murder charges. She called Diablo about Teresa being a journalist, which led to the murder order, but she did not order or participate in the killing. The show pivots away from her as a suspect; DA explicitly states insufficient evidence to prosecute. No public exposure occurred; questioning was contained to police interrogation room.

police_conduct_quote: Here's how it works, Alberto. You give us whoever shot this girl in the back three times, we take him in and that's that. You play games, we run Lola through the system and good luck getting your kid back from Child Services.
quote_or_scene: Detectives visit Beto in prison, accuse him of ordering the hit. He denies: 'No way I green-lit this girl. You think I need this kind of heat when I'm about to walk out of here?' Later revealed Diablo ordered the hit without Beto's knowledge because the child Beto thought was his was actually Diablo's.
notes: Beto was the initial theory as gang leader whose girlfriend (Lola) vouched for Teresa. Detectives assumed he ordered the hit. However, it's later revealed Diablo acted independently because Lola's son was actually Diablo's child, not Beto's. Beto explicitly denies involvement and notes he's up for parole, wouldn't want this heat. Interrogation contained to prison; no public exposure beyond that setting. The 'wrongful conviction' tag applies because the false accusation potentially impacts his parole eligibility.

police_conduct_quote: Your father's smuggling them in to you. Contraband for L-12. In exchange for protection? Doesn't seem to be working. You've been in the infirmary three times in the last six months.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Patterson in prison, suggest he's complicit in the murder conspiracy. Patterson responds: 'My dad's got his problems, I got mine.' Later, DA McCoy states: 'We won't prosecute your son for conspiracy. He'll be eligible for parole in two years.' Patterson is ultimately released after his father testifies.
notes: Patterson was accused of conspiracy to murder based on his involvement in smuggling contraband cell phones that facilitated the murder plot. However, he was a victim of gang coercion (assaulted multiple times) and his father was acting under duress to protect him. DA explicitly chose not to prosecute him for conspiracy and arranged his release. While the accusation occurred in prison (not fully public), the threat of conspiracy murder charges and interrogation constitutes exposure severity 2. He was already incarcerated for an unrelated drug offense.

quote_or_scene: Defense attorney Robinette cross-examines: 'Convicted of solicitation. How many times?' 'Four.' 'Have you ever had gonorrhea?' Isabella is forced to publicly admit her criminal and medical history in open court.
notes: Isabella Perez was a victim of unauthorized sterilization by Nurse Rhodes, not accused of the murder. However, she was publicly humiliated in court when her criminal history (solicitation convictions, STD history) was exposed during cross-examination as part of the defense strategy. This represents harm from public exposure of past accusations/convictions in service of discrediting her as a witness. While not a 'false accusation' in the traditional sense, her past arrests are used to publicly shame her. Including for completeness as she suffered reputational harm from exposure of old accusations.

police_conduct_quote: FONTANA: 'Mr. Monroe, where were you between noon and 2:00 this afternoon?' MONROE: 'What? Wait, wait, wait, listen.' FONTANA: 'The sooner we rule you out, the sooner we can focus on other suspects.' MONROE: 'Rule me out? I didn't kill Chelsea.' GREEN: 'Look, nobody's saying you did. But right now, everybody's a suspect.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives question Monroe about his whereabouts during the murder window, implying he's a suspect. He provides alibi of being at work filing patient intake forms.
notes: Monroe is cleared early via alibi. No public exposure occurred - questioning was private at crime scene. He's the victim's partner and believed father of the baby, making him an obvious initial suspect. Later devastated to learn via DNA test that the baby is not his biological child, but this harm is unrelated to the murder accusation.

police_conduct_quote: GREEN: 'If you were involved in this murder and this kidnapping, you're gonna wanna come off that position.' STOLL: 'Man, you're way off base.'
quote_or_scene: McCoy develops theory that Stoll conspired with Arlene to sell the baby and murdered Chelsea. Arlene testifies: 'Frank came running out of the apartment in a panic. He said something had gone wrong... Chelsea was lying on the floor, and there was blood all around her head.' Stoll was arraigned and remanded to Rikers.
tags: fabricated_claim; circumstantial_case; prosecutorial_overreach; arrested; indicted; public_trial
notes: Stoll admits to being at the apartment during the murder timeframe and to being the baby's biological father. He admits planning to sell the baby but denies the murder. Arlene Tarrington takes a plea deal and testifies that Stoll committed the murder, but her credibility is questionable given her own criminal involvement and insanity defense. The prosecution's case relies heavily on her testimony. Transcript cuts off during cross-examination before verdict, but the episode structure suggests Arlene may be the actual killer and is framing Stoll. However, definitive innocence cannot be confirmed from truncated transcript. Marking as 'strongly_implied_innocent' based on narrative trajectory suggesting Arlene is unreliable.

police_conduct_quote: Can you account for yourself, at about 6:00 this morning? ... You're saying that's a reason to kill him? You tell us.
quote_or_scene: LESTER: Look, fellas, scratch an inch into Stack's life, you'll find 20 stories like mine. // GREEN: Damn, look at his lifestyle. // BRISCOE: Hey, wait a second. Are you telling us that it doesn't add up with the business?
notes: Wilkes was a former driver Stack fired after Wilkes was arrested in Texas for carrying a gun (which Stack had told him to carry). Wilkes assaulted Stack when fired and had motive. However, detectives pivot away from him after finding Stack's smuggling operation and cars, suggesting other motives. No public exposure or material harm beyond police questioning, so severity is minimal.

quote_or_scene: DEFENSE: Or did you just see your best shot at citizenship? // ALVAREZ: No. I saw him, that man. // DEFENSE: Ten years in our country, Ms. Alvarez, you ever pay taxes? ... Did you ever pay taxes? // ALVAREZ: No. // ... // McCOY: Immigration cases are clogging the federal courts. It's no time to be making personal appeals. And even if you could, Judge Todd would think we bought her testimony. It can't be helped.
tags: witness_recant; fabricated_claim; public_trial; immigrant; ruined_in_family; ruined_financially
notes: Blanca Alvarez is a key witness who saw Prentiss hide the murder weapon. Defense attorney publicly accuses her in open court of fabricating testimony to obtain citizenship, exposing her undocumented status and tax evasion. She was also physically attacked/nearly kidnapped by Dan Moncrief (hired by Terry Dorn) to intimidate her. The courtroom exposure and attack qualify as severe harm. Ultimately faces deportation in two months, separating her from her husband, children, and mother who all live in the US. Episode ends with McCoy unable to help her avoid deportation. While she is a witness rather than accused of the primary crime (murder), she is publicly accused of perjury/fabrication in court and suffers life-altering consequences (deportation, family separation, physical attack). This is a complex case but meets the threshold: accused of lying, proven/implied truthful (her testimony holds up), publicly exposed in court, and faces deportation.

police_conduct_quote: With all due respect, Lieutenant, what does a Arab have to do with a dead white guy?... Isn't this the flag of Hamas?... So it wouldn't spike your blood pressure if I threw it in the gutter?
quote_or_scene: LIBDEH: 'I was cleared, 100%!' Detectives confront him at his laundromat based on Councilman's claim he 'harasses the congregation' and was questioned about previous arson. GREEN: 'If you have any involvement with the dead person at the synagogue, let's get in front of it now.' LIBDEH: 'He's no one I know. I heard it was a white guy.'
notes: Accused based on neighborhood tensions and prior arson investigation. Detectives brought him in for questioning with antagonistic tactics (threatened to throw Hamas calendar in gutter). Cleared when victim identified as Jeffrey Kilgore. Exposure appears limited to police interrogation; no evidence of broader public exposure or material consequences beyond the hostile questioning itself. Does not meet threshold for inclusion as consequence_severity 1 with police_only exposure.

quote_or_scene: KAYLA WATSON (girlfriend): 'They said on TV that Jeff tore up a Jewish bible.' She is confused because 'Jeff didn't have anything against them.' Eric Speicher later admits: 'I paid Kilgore to go to the synagogue and mess up the book.' Kilgore was a hired contractor, not a hate crime perpetrator.
tags: murdered; media_outing; wrong_ID; fabricated_claim; hate_crime; blue_collar
notes: Though Kilgore is the murder victim, he was publicly accused (via media coverage) of committing an anti-Semitic hate crime/desecration. He was actually a paid contractor hired by Eric Speicher. His girlfriend indicates TV coverage portrayed him as having torn up a Jewish bible out of hatred. He suffered the ultimate harm (murder) but also reputational harm as a hate criminal when he was innocent of that motive. The actual desecration was commercial, not ideological. He is innocent of hate crime accusations, though he did commit burglary/destruction of property as hired.

police_conduct_quote: I framed one of Fleckner's buddies on a drug murder. A lowlife named Anton Brady.
quote_or_scene: CERULLO (on stand): 'I framed one of Fleckner's buddies on a drug murder. A lowlife named Anton Brady.'
notes: Cerullo admits on the stand to framing Brady on a drug murder. Brady is described as one of 'Fleckner's buddies' who 'ran with' Fleckner. The transcript indicates motions for new trials were filed after Cerullo's confession. This is a wrongful conviction case where the framing cop later admits to fabricating evidence.

police_conduct_quote: Another guy he ran with, Jimmy Mills. I sent him up on a rape beef.
quote_or_scene: CERULLO (on stand): 'Another guy he ran with, Jimmy Mills. I sent him up on a rape beef.' Context: Cerullo is admitting to framing people in his career.
notes: Cerullo admits on the stand to framing Mills on rape charges. Mills is described as another person who 'ran with' Fleckner. The context of Cerullo's testimony is that he's admitting to framing 'a lot of bad guys in my day' to establish why Fleckner would have reason to kill him. The episode ends noting that motions for new trials have been filed based on Cerullo's admissions.

police_conduct_quote: Look, bro, you sell guns to kids. That's serious enough. You add murder to that...
quote_or_scene: Police raid Biso's gun shop, arrest him in front of young customers. Detectives: 'Police! Get down! Get down!' Then: 'Unless there's some other Biso. Dude was a journalist? That nutcase?' Biso provides alibi confirmed by neighbors; detectives move on.
notes: Biso was investigated because victim Tadhg had scheduled a meeting with him and Tadhg's notebook indicated concern about Biso's illegal gun sales. Detectives arrested Biso at his shop in front of customers, accused him of murder, and threatened him with serious charges. Biso's alibi (confirmed by neighbors) cleared him. Though he was guilty of illegal gun sales (arrested for that), he was innocent of the murder accusation that brought the public raid and interrogation.

police_conduct_quote: Oh, come on! He had a kid with another woman. You're the scorned woman. You got revenge. Admit it!
quote_or_scene: Detectives: 'Oh, come on! He had a kid with another woman. You're the scorned woman. You got revenge. Admit it!' Angela: 'No, Tadhg needed my help. He wanted to die. All I did was help him!' Later indicted for murder two, publicly tried, eventually plea to assisted suicide (man two, 3 years) after evidence showed it was assisted suicide, not premeditated murder.
notes: Angela was indicted for murder two based on prosecution theory she murdered Tadhg out of jealous revenge. Evidence later showed she assisted his suicide (still a crime, but not murder). She was publicly tried, cross-examined, and exposed in court. The murder accusation was excessive given the assisted suicide reality; she eventually pled to man two (assisted suicide) with 3-year sentence. Marked 'partially_involved' because she did assist a suicide (illegal) but was innocent of the MURDER charge that brought the public trial and greater exposure/harm.

police_conduct_quote: Attempted murder of a police officer is what you're looking at. Ballistics is checking into that gun of yours. My guess is it's gonna tie you to Danny's murder.
quote_or_scene: Ballistics on the boy's .38. It's not the murder weapon. You're kidding me.
notes: Shawn was arrested after shooting at police during tunnel raid. Detectives believed his .38 would match Danny's murder weapon based on motive (Danny stole his girlfriend Tina). Ballistics cleared him. He had active warrants and escaped from Bellevue, so exposure was contained to police interaction, but he was arrested and faced attempted murder charges for shooting at detective.

quote_or_scene: John Ashburn, you're under arrest for the murder of Danny Ashburn. ... Allison, what the hell is going on here? ... Where's my wife? She's being interviewed right now.
notes: John was arrested at his home in front of his wife after police found the murder weapon. He had motive (fed up with stepson), opportunity (E-ZPass records showed GW Bridge trip), and the gun was found in his house. His wife Allison later confessed to the actual murder. He was publicly arrested and his two other children were present. The arrest and accusation occurred at his home with family present, constituting public exposure in the family domain.

police_conduct_quote: You were mad at Derek because of the money. You got in a fight and things got out of hand.
quote_or_scene: Mark Rhodes tells detectives: 'Lucas Brody. Him and Derek had words at The Baby Doll.' Detectives later find Brody passed out drunk in his office. Brody: 'Derek's dead? How?' Detective: 'You don't know nothing about it?' Brody: 'No... I didn't kill him.'
notes: Brody was publicly questioned at his workplace (Morgan Keener office) by detectives who found him drunk and unconscious. Detectives accused him based on reported argument with victim over bonus disparity. Cell phone records and bartender confirmations cleared him. He quit his job, likely due to bonus disappointment and possibly the public accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Your white SUV, it's under a microscope in our lab. We found Derek's blood and his hair. Explain that... He was in back of the SUV. And he was either dead or dying when you hauled him to the dumpsite.
quote_or_scene: Detective: 'Your white SUV, it's under a microscope in our lab. We found Derek's blood and his hair.' Robert was arrested and brought to precinct. Later cooperated and received deal after explaining he helped dispose of body after the murder but wasn't present when Derek died. E-Z Pass records showed he entered Manhattan at 3:20am, after Derek's time of death (midnight-2am).
tags: arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; business_exec; murder_case; circumstantial_case
notes: Robert White was Sophia Keener's estranged husband in bitter custody dispute. Forensic evidence (Derek's blood/hair in his white SUV) led to his arrest for murder. He was publicly arrested and brought in for questioning. He was innocent of the murder itself but guilty of helping dispose of the body (accessory after the fact). Time-stamped E-Z Pass records proved he couldn't have been present during the murder (midnight-2am) as he didn't enter Manhattan until 3:20am. He ultimately cooperated against Sophia in exchange for misdemeanor plea on body disposal.

quote_or_scene: Security guard: 'Better back off, Mr. Grant. I'm going to have to detain you, sir.' ... Ex-wife Cheryl: 'Imagine my surprise when Mrs. Fogarty knocks on my door and tells me that the man I married, father of my only child, is being lead away from his place of employment in handcuffs.'
tags: public_confrontation; arrested; ruined_at_work; family_present; coerced_participation; victim_of_kidnapping_plot
notes: Grant robbed his own bank only because kidnappers held his daughter hostage and threatened to kill her. He was publicly detained/arrested at his workplace (the bank) in front of colleagues and customers. His ex-wife mentions he was 'lead away from his place of employment in handcuffs.' Though he fired a gun killing accomplice Cyrus Lowell, this was defensive/under duress. Detectives quickly establish he was coerced once they learn about daughter Julie's kidnapping.

police_conduct_quote: Ten decks of heroin within 1,000 feet of a school? That's 'B' felony territory. 'B' felony, that's nine years, bro.
quote_or_scene: DETECTIVE: 'Fifteen of your boys and their hootchie-mamas isn't gonna make an alibi for you!' PRIM: 'I swear on my grandmother I ain't do this!'
notes: Carlos (victim's nephew) told police Prim had motive after being pepper-sprayed. Prim was arrested with 10 decks of heroin, interrogated aggressively about murder, threatened with 9-year sentence. His alibi (15 witnesses at bodega across street) was verified by bodega owner. Gave police Jeremy Miller's name. Exposure appears limited to police interrogation, but arrest itself is public harm (severity 2).

quote_or_scene: PAMELA HENSON: 'Three months ago, Child Services took her to court and had her charged with abuse.' ORDERLY: 'That abuse charge was ludicrous! And it wasn't for physical abuse, it was because I stopped giving Emily her AIDS medication.' HENSON (on stand): 'That's when he called in Child Services to take Emily away.'
notes: Foster mother charged with child abuse by Child Services at Dr. Copelan's instigation. The 'abuse' was taking Emily off medication that was making her sicker. Emily improved off meds (gained weight, could walk, smiled). Henson tried alternative treatment (mumbala khan root). Lost custody of Emily. Defense attorney implied at trial that Henson's actions killed Emily, but context shows Dr. Copelan's over-medication was the actual cause. No indication charges were formally dropped, but she's treated as cleared. Public court exposure plus loss of child = severity 3.

quote_or_scene: Lieutenant: 'Well, as of this morning, what you are is a suspect, on modified assignment, with no gun or shield. And the sooner you accept that, the better.'
tags: public_questioning_at_work; suspended; ruined_at_work; cop; murder_case; wrong_ID; fabricated_claim
notes: Falco is suspended and stripped of gun/shield in front of colleagues. He is the primary suspect throughout most of the investigation. His apartment is the crime scene. The show strongly implies he is innocent - drugged by Sonia, then framed by Angela Young as revenge. Defense attorney publicly accuses him of planting evidence and murder in court testimony.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Keisha during arrest: 'Hey, I've had enough of you, shut it.' And physical handling implied during arrest.
quote_or_scene: Rowen: 'We've come across information that leads us to believe Angela Young set up your client to kill Sonia Vasquez.' Final verdict: 'We find the defendant, Keisha Sipes, not guilty.'
tags: public_trial; indicted; arrested; acquitted_after_trial; wrong_ID; fabricated_claim
notes: Keisha is arrested, indicted, and tried for Sonia's murder. The prosecution believes she had motive (Sonia pregnant with her boyfriend's baby) and evidence (bloody shoes in her dumpster). At trial's end, evidence emerges that Angela Young orchestrated the murder and framed Keisha. She is acquitted. The show strongly implies Angela manipulated Keisha into committing the murder or framed her entirely. Either way, the formal legal process (arrest, trial, public accusation) caused significant harm.

police_conduct_quote: Falco to Tyrell: 'You're a criminal. You're dirt!'
quote_or_scene: Fontana: 'Both Sim Var and Sonia were reading books just like that one.' Green: 'That would explain the mixed crew.' Fontana: 'Looks like Tyrell found himself a new way to recruit.' Later, detectives bring Tyrell in for questioning about the robbery crew and murder conspiracy.
notes: Tyrell is brought in for questioning on suspicion of coaching/running the robbery crew and orchestrating Sonia's murder as revenge against Falco. Detectives theorize he's behind it all. Falco publicly degrades him. Later evidence shows Angela (his ex-wife) was actually running the crew and orchestrated the murders. Tyrell is exonerated by the narrative pivot. However, exposure appears limited to the interrogation room - no indication it spread beyond police. Borderline inclusion due to limited public exposure, but the public confrontation and insults from Falco in front of other detectives qualifies as severity 2.

police_conduct_quote: You're our witness. We own your ass... Help us apprehend these men or all deals are off... You want to withhold information, you can do it from a cell in Rikers... And you better believe they'll get to you in there.
quote_or_scene: Andreas initially arrested in fraud raid for selling pirated DVDs and stolen NYPD equipment. Released on ROR to cooperate. His wife Danielle, mother-in-law, and two children are murdered by the home invaders while trying to lure him back. Andreas: 'I used to come here every Sunday with my two kids. No wife, no work. Two hours a week where everything seemed okay. And now I got them all killed, didn't I?'
tags: business_exec; witness_turned_victim; family_murdered; ruined_at_work; public_raid; arrested; protective_custody; coerced_cooperation
notes: Andreas was selling stolen police equipment and made fake DEA badges, but is innocent of the home invasion murders. His cooperation with prosecution led to his family being targeted and killed. The public raid on his store and his arrest exposed him, making him a target for the killers who feared he would identify them.

quote_or_scene: Andreas reveals: 'Dave Morley. He tends bar at Alberta's on Avenue A. He's the guy I asked. He might know where they are.' Van Buren reports: 'The bartender Andreas gave up, this guy Morley, he took his back pay two days ago and left town.'

She suffered arrest, legal process, and reputation damage before exoneration. Prosecution dropped charges after Ashcroft's testimony and evidence pointed to Felner. He was proven innocent because he received full payment and left before murder occurred, plus his description of the woman he saw matched Lucy.

Financial harm ($250M loss) preceded but was not caused by accusation.

Charged with assaulting officer and resisting arrest (separate from murder accusation), but murder accusation was the cause of the confrontation.

He was publicly chased through a flea market and arrested. He was cleared when he provided alibi (at halfway house with supervisor who watches like a hawk) and explained Stanton was recruiting ex-cons for legitimate pizza business, which Spall wanted no part of. The real killer (Jesse Erickson) was later identified through surveillance video.

police_conduct_quote: We know who you are. We know about your past. So cut the crap and tell us what's going on.
quote_or_scene: Detective: 'Tell us about Eli Barone.' / Kapinski: 'We had a session, and then he left, very much alive.' / Kapinski shows video proving Eli left his apartment alive at 10:07 PM.
notes: Kapinski is a registered sex offender (convicted as teen for sexting photo of girlfriend), which made him an easy initial target. Video evidence from his own phone proves Eli left alive. Arrested and brought to precinct but released when alibi confirmed. No public exposure beyond police questioning.

quote_or_scene: Defense Attorney in court: 'You had romantic feelings for him, didn't you?' / Gilbert: 'No.' / Defense shows photo: 'Okay, that's not what it looks like. I was just teaching him how to hold a baseball bat. Okay, his father just died. I was consoling him.' / Defense: 'Sir, isn't it true that Eli kicked in your door because he wanted to confront you about what you did to him, and you shot him because you didn't want people to know?'
notes: Gilbert shot Eli in legitimate self-defense when Eli kicked in his door (as part of social media stunt). Gilbert initially lied about finding the body due to unlicensed gun. Defense attorney publicly accused him in open court of being a pedophile who had 'romantic feelings' for Eli and killed him to cover up abuse. This false accusation was made despite Gilbert's established self-defense claim. Price calls it 'baseless and inflammatory' but judge allows it. Gilbert forced to defend himself publicly against pedophilia allegations in addition to shooting. ADA Maroun notes 'I can't believe the judge let her do that, as if that guy hasn't been through enough.'

quote_or_scene: Detectives chase Nathan at bar: 'Give me your hands.' Nathan: 'I only ran because I had coke on me.' Squad clears him after alibi checks out.
notes: Victim's friend reported Nathan followed Emily to library after argument. He fled from police due to cocaine possession, was briefly detained and questioned, but alibi verified and he was cleared of murder.

police_conduct_quote: Detective: 'We think you threatened to kill her.' Detective to Bobby: 'We think you need to explain why you were sending her threatening texts.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Bobby at his Sheepshead Bay apartment about threatening DM: 'I'm so angry, I could kill you.' Bobby: 'You think I did this? I loved her.' Key card alibi clears him.
notes: Emily's boyfriend sent angry text saying 'I could kill you' after discovering she was dressed up and leaving when he surprised her with tickets. Detectives traveled to Brooklyn to question him based on the threatening message. Cleared via electronic key card alibi showing he was at his loft during murder.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Cosgrove to Sherman after he refuses to talk: 'You're on parole. You're not going anywhere.' Physical confrontation ensues. Detective: 'We got a church too. And putting hands on my partner, that's a sin.'
quote_or_scene: Sherman arrested at church, tried for murder. Prosecution offers plea deals (man one 10 years). Sherman initially cooperates, revealing Pastor Mike hired him, then recants on stand: 'I was lying because I wanted a deal.' Case proceeds against Pastor Mike instead.
tags: murder_case; public_trial; perp_walk; arrested; indicted; clergy; ex_con; witness_tampering_victim
notes: Sherman was the actual shooter acting under orders from Pastor Mike Butler in murder-for-hire. Initially charged with murder two, cooperated and received plea deal for man one/10 years after revealing Pastor Mike hired him. Later recanted testimony (likely due to witness tampering by Pastor Mike's lawyer). While he committed the shooting, he was a hired killer rather than having personal motive, and took plea deal trading up to real mastermind. Partially involved but public trial/arrest caused significant exposure and legal consequences.

quote_or_scene: Waitress testifies: 'I just remember feeling really disappointed... The fact Matisse did nothing to protect his lady.' Shaw to witness: 'My advice has always been, never meet your heroes.' Price in opening: 'He screws up our homicide investigation to protect his fake tough guy image.'
tags: ruined_in_family; reputation_destroyed; media_outing; celebrity; murder_case; public_trial
notes: Matisse paid $100k to delete surveillance video showing him running to bathroom instead of protecting Hannah. Was arrested and charged with obstruction/tampering. Though cleared of murder, his cowardice became public knowledge through trial testimony, destroying his tough-guy rapper image. The waitress's testimony and detectives' comments show his reputation for cowardice spread publicly. He did commit obstruction (paying to delete video) but was innocent of the murder accusation.

quote_or_scene: Defense attorney cross-examination: 'So you admit that you were a coward on the night in question.' Riley: 'No, I do not. I do not admit that. I just... I just didn't respond the way that I should have... But I'm a good cop.' Later: 'Story just broke.' 'What story?' 'Riley committed suicide a couple hours ago.' Riley's relative confronts Price: 'Son of a bitch! I hope you're happy! Hope you feel good about all this, ruining the life of a good cop!'
tags: suicide; public_trial; media_outing; ruined_at_work; reputation_destroyed; cop; murder_case
notes: Riley initially lied to detectives about his arrival time and seeing the shooter because he froze in his patrol car instead of engaging. Price threatened him with criminal charges to force truthful testimony: 'if your story proves to be inaccurate... I will file criminal charges, which means you will lose your job and your pension.' At trial, defense attorney publicly branded him a coward repeatedly. Story broke in newspapers (Price reads about it at newsstand). Riley committed suicide hours after verdict. His relative blamed Price for 'ruining the life of a good cop.' Riley did lie to investigators (obstruction) but the PRIMARY accusation driving the harm was cowardice/dereliction of duty, which led to public humiliation and suicide. The lying was secondary to the core accusation of failing to act.

quote_or_scene: Daniel Deluca posted on neighborhood safety app: 'Be careful. There's a dangerous Black man in the area. He's armed. Exercise extreme caution.' Post included Marshall's picture. Burke saw posts saying 'A tall Black man just mugged someone. The mugger is armed and extremely dangerous.' Burke testified: 'I thought he had a gun... I believed what [Deluca] posted. I thought that I was in danger.'
tags: fabricated_claim; media_outing; ruined_physically; murdered; wrong_ID; doctor; minority
notes: Dr. Marshall was falsely portrayed on social media app as armed and dangerous criminal by Deluca. This led Burke to kill him with a wine bottle. Marshall was completely innocent - he was a respected heart surgeon simply walking to meet someone. The false accusation was spread via social media app to hundreds in the neighborhood, causing public exposure and ultimately his death. Deluca's motive was financial - driving down property values to buy real estate cheaply.

police_conduct_quote: Officers Wagner and Farley: 'Hands in the air! Now! Get on the ground. Do it now. Don't do it. [guns drawn] Calm down! Stand still! Comply!' Shaw: 'I'm a detective with the 2-7. My shield is in my coat. I'm just gonna show you my shield, OK? This doesn't have to escalate. You're making a mistake!' Later, officer threatens Shaw: 'You're gonna be sorry!' and 'I'd think real hard about your next move.'
quote_or_scene: Shaw's partner Frank Cosgrove witnesses the confrontation: 'What the hell are you doing? That's my partner! We're on the job! We're detectives of the 2-7! Get off him!' Officers Wagner and Farley later file Internal Affairs complaint against Shaw. IA Sergeant Matthews tells Shaw: 'Officers Wagner and Farley filed a complaint against you... If you drop your complaint, I'm confident they will too.' Outcome: 'Internal Affairs is closing the investigation [into Wagner/Farley]. They found your allegations to be unsubstantiated... [Their] complaint stuck. They're suspending you for a week without pay.'
tags: wrong_ID; ruined_at_work; public_confrontation; suspended; cop; minority; witness_recant
notes: Shaw was racially profiled by officers Wagner and Farley who assumed he was a murder suspect solely based on him being a Black man in the area. Despite identifying himself as a detective and attempting to show his badge, officers held him at gunpoint, forced him down, and physically restrained him. When Shaw filed a complaint, he faced retaliation through a counter-complaint alleging he violated policy by not complying. The IA investigation exonerated the officers and suspended Shaw for a week without pay. The accusation was public - witnessed by Shaw's partner Cosgrove and occurred in the street. Shaw's career was harmed (suspension) and he faced institutional retaliation for reporting racial profiling.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Hopkins at hospital: 'According to the chief of surgery, you're not allowed to see patients anymore, right? You're on administrative duty... We understand that Dr. Marshall had something to do with that... We got you on video two hours before Dr. Marshall was killed. You were yelling at him. You shoved him into a wall. Plus, we know that Dr. Marshall was accusing you of misconduct.' Hopkins responds: 'I think I'd like to contact my attorney. I think that attorney should meet you down to the precinct.' Later cleared: 'Dr. Hopkins's alibi checks out. He went to the theater with his wife. Saw Othello... Then they had dinner, car service home. So I got ticket stubs, credit card receipts, and video.'
notes: Dr. Hopkins was publicly accused at his workplace (hospital) of murdering Dr. Marshall. Detectives questioned him in front of colleagues about video showing him shoving Marshall and about Marshall's accusations of medical misconduct. Hopkins was already on administrative duty due to Marshall's complaints. He was brought to the precinct for questioning. His alibi (theater, dinner, video evidence) fully exonerated him. While he had workplace conflict with Marshall, he was innocent of the murder. The public workplace confrontation and precinct questioning constitute harm even though he was quickly cleared.

police_conduct_quote: I hate to break the news to you, buddy, but when it comes to being a victim, Ackerman's definitely got you beat... He was murdered this morning. And you happened to threaten to do that to him three days ago, brother.
quote_or_scene: The keypad entry system at the recording studio confirms Lamar Cordell was there at the time of the murder. - So he's not our killer.
notes: Cordell sent threatening DM to Ackerman ('gonna do to him what the Jews did to Jesus') but had solid alibi via keypad entry records. Victim's son accused him directly. Exposure remained with police only - no public naming or media coverage shown.

police_conduct_quote: You think you can stop us, but you can't. This is a movement. Revelation is coming. - I think you mean incarceration.
quote_or_scene: We got video of Hobbs on the subway platform near Ackerman's brownstone boarding a Bronx-bound train ten minutes before Ackerman's neighbor called 911. And he wasn't wearing a green jacket, as your witness described. - So he's telling the truth. - Yeah, it looks that way.
notes: Hobbs vandalized Ackerman's house with anti-Semitic graffiti the morning of murder. His fingerprints on spray paint can led to arrest for murder. Cleared via subway video showing him leaving area before murder in different clothing than witness description. Was arrested and formally charged with hate crime (graffiti/criminal mischief), but these were murder-related charges that were proven false. The arrest itself constitutes material harm even though exposure remained with police.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Bardo: 'This is about the fact that your lawyer turned up dead after you were seen following her yesterday.' Bardo responds: 'I wasn't. She asked me to sign this affidavit for my case, so I was dropping it off.' He alibis at Papaya King until 8:00 p.m.
notes: Client of the victim with violent priors. Security footage shows him following Rachel, but he was delivering an affidavit at her request. Alibi verified at restaurant. Arrested but quickly cleared.

quote_or_scene: Detectives chase Luis at a basketball court and arrest him: 'Luis Cortez, we need a word.' Luis runs. They find 'a gun. And a knife' plus Rachel's address. Detective asks: 'What's with the arsenal?' Luis later explains he sent roses to apologize. Phone data puts him in Brooklyn at time of murder.
notes: Son of Rachel's convicted client. Had threatened Rachel in court after his father's sentencing, calling her 'stupid bitch' and saying 'it was all her fault.' Found with weapons and victim's address, but sent flowers as apology. Phone records and knife analysis clear him. Arrested publicly at basketball court in front of peers.

quote_or_scene: Grassley confronts detectives at his home, intoxicated and belligerent. Detectives ask about his confrontation with Rachel at Luchardi's restaurant. He explains: 'My 16-year-old daughter was raped and murdered by one of her clients in July. And Bender got him acquitted last week.' Restaurant owner confirms public altercation. Grassley arrested for obstruction but cleared of murder after alibi at bar confirmed.
notes: Father of rape/murder victim whose killer Rachel successfully defended. Publicly confronted Rachel at Luchardi's restaurant, screaming at her. Arrested at his home while intoxicated and confrontational with police. Alibi confirmed at bar across street. Grieving father with clear motive but proven elsewhere during murder.

police_conduct_quote: You are part of Antifa, right? / We got video of you in the neighborhood of a U.S. congresswoman whose husband was beaten to death, five minutes before his murder. And we just caught you walking around with a nightstick and devil photos of the same congresswoman. Do the math. / You get to her house, she's not there, so you murdered the husband?
quote_or_scene: NYPD. We need to talk to the owner, Paul Koening. [At his workplace coffee shop] / Where are you running to, Paul? / I didn't do anything. / You sure about that? / DNA wasn't able to find any traces of blood on the baton. / So he's not our killer. / All right. Cut him loose.
notes: Paul Koening is arrested at his workplace (coffee shop) in front of customers/coworkers. He is detained, forced to provide DNA, and interrogated aggressively with threats about murder charges. DNA test proves he is not the killer and he is released. The arrest and confrontation at his workplace constitute public exposure and material harm (severity 3: arrest + public exposure).

quote_or_scene: Detectives question him about threatening texts he sent to Elliot. He says: 'I sent some stupid texts... I was just pissed... Son of a bitch persuaded me to partner up with his firm... Then two months after the deal closes, he fires me.' He provides alibi: 'I was in my apartment drinking Scotch. I ordered some Chinese food around 9:00. Ask my doorman.' Detectives verify alibi and investigation shifts to Aaron Cole who later confesses.
notes: This person was the first suspect pursued by detectives due to threatening texts sent after being fired. He had to beef up security because Elliot was 'so concerned' about him. He was questioned by police, exposed as a suspect to his employer/workplace context (implied by needing to provide alibi through doorman and discussing work relationship), but was cleared when Aaron Cole confessed. Qualifies as harm due to public exposure as suspect despite being innocent - severity 2 for public exposure without formal arrest.

quote_or_scene: Detectives question Greyson at his workplace about the threatening email he sent Madison: 'I've been patient, but it's time to pay. Otherwise, it isn't going to end well.' He is questioned in front of colleagues about Madison's disappearance and murder suspicions.
notes: Greyson owed $500k for fake NFT Madison sold him. His threatening email made him initial suspect. He provided timestamped recording proving he left gallery at 9:51pm before murder at ~12:24am. Security footage confirmed his departure. Questioned at his workplace in professional setting, constituting public exposure though no formal charges filed.

police_conduct_quote: Detective: 'Well, you can, and tell 'em to meet you down at our precinct 'cause you're under arrest.' Context: after landlord refused to explain surveillance cameras in tenant apartments.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest landlord after discovering he had surveillance cameras in Sarah Baker's apartment. Detective says: 'I'm arresting you for obstruction.' Landlord arrested and taken to precinct. Building surveillance shows he only left building for 25 minutes, not long enough to commit murder across town.
notes: Marquette was spying on female tenants via hidden cameras, including Sarah Baker who filed housing complaint against him. This made him suspect in her murder. He was arrested for obstruction when refusing to cooperate. However, building surveillance proved he was only out of building 25 minutes on murder night - insufficient time to travel to gallery and commit murder. Cleared of murder but guilty of voyeurism/illegal surveillance (different crime). Included because murder accusation led to arrest despite later being cleared of that specific charge.

person_label: Detective Vincent Riley (interviewer who cleared suspect)
quote_or_scene: PRICE: 'Shortly after interviewing the defendant, you were suspended from the NYPD.' RILEY: 'That's correct.' PRICE: 'For attacking a captain while drunk.' ... PRICE: 'You drink alcohol while you're on the clock working as a police officer?' ... PRICE: 'So when you interviewed the defendant, you were under incredible stress, you were drinking.' ... PRICE: 'OK, but the point here, Detective, is that you drank while at work during this period of time and you were under extraordinary stress, which means your assessment of the defendant's guilt or innocence is absolutely meaningless.'
notes: Riley is not accused of a crime per se, but is publicly accused in open court of being an unreliable/incompetent detective due to drinking on the job and poor judgment. This is done by the prosecution (Price) to impeach his credibility after defense used his testimony to suggest Elliot was innocent. The accusation is that Riley's professional judgment was 'absolutely meaningless' - effectively accusing him of investigative incompetence. Riley is proven innocent of this accusation in the sense that: (1) he did NOT drink the day he interviewed Elliot ('I didn't drink that day'), (2) his suspension was for a one-time punch defending Dixon from sexist abuse, not chronic drinking, and (3) his assessment of Elliot turned out to be WRONG (Elliot was guilty), but that doesn't mean Riley was drunk/incompetent at the time. The harm is severe public humiliation in a packed courtroom with media present, damaging his reputation as 'one of the best detectives in the entire NYPD.' Price later apologizes partially ('I know it wasn't pleasant, but you did the right thing for Celeste').

police_conduct_quote: We can always parade you past your colleagues in cuffs, take you downtown. Maybe that'll make you more comfortable.
quote_or_scene: Detective Shaw threatens: 'We can always parade you past your colleagues in cuffs, take you downtown.' Sargento is confronted at his workplace after being caught on security footage assaulting Barlowe outside a bar. Traffic cam footage later proves he slept in his car all night, clearing him.
notes: Sargento lost $280 million due to Barlowe's stock manipulation and was fired from his previous job. He confronted and assaulted Barlowe the night of the murder but was cleared by traffic cam showing he slept in his car. The threat to parade him in cuffs past colleagues constitutes public workplace exposure even though he wasn't arrested.

quote_or_scene: Detective: 'And now you're back on the very day that he turns up dead. Pretty big coincidence.' She is questioned about being in New York the day of the murder and asked for DNA swab, which she consents to. DNA comparison clears her.
notes: EXCLUDED: While questioned as a suspect, there is no indication of public exposure beyond police interrogation. She was staying at a hotel and questioned privately. The interrogation was pointed but not threatening, and she consented to DNA testing. No harm beyond the interrogation itself is shown or implied. Does not meet threshold for inclusion as consequence_severity = 1 with no public exposure.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Shaw: 'We got some pretty compelling video that supports our point of view.' When she refuses to talk: 'Well, in that case, you're coming with us.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives approach Melissa James while she is with her boss. Shaw: 'NYPD. Your assistant told us we'd find you here. We want to talk to you about Jonah Barlowe.' Boss asks: 'Melissa, everything okay?' She initially denies knowing Barlowe, then detectives threaten: 'We got some pretty compelling video that supports our point of view... Well, in that case, you're coming with us.' Her alibi (birthday party with new boyfriend) is later confirmed.
notes: Melissa James is confronted by police in front of her boss about her BDSM relationship with the murder victim. This constitutes public workplace exposure of her private sexual activities. Though her alibi clears her, the confrontation in front of her employer about being the dominatrix of a murder victim represents significant professional harm and embarrassment.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives show him video of altercation and confront him about attacking Joyner: 'Is this you trying to imply that Joyner was gay?' 'You follow him down the subway, try to finish the fight?'
quote_or_scene: Paige's car service confirms his alibi. Detectives move on after verifying he left the scene immediately after the altercation.
notes: Paige had a public altercation with Joyner that was recorded and posted to social media, making him an obvious suspect. However, exposure was limited to police interrogation with no evidence of broader public accusation of murder.

police_conduct_quote: 'Keep on like this, and you're gonna end up dead.' You didn't send that message? [Confrontational questioning] 'We are aware of your prior for aggravated assault.' [Bringing up past to pressure him]
quote_or_scene: Detectives question Zane, reference his threatening text messages and prior assault conviction. He explains the message was about Joyner's self-hatred regarding being closeted. Provides alibi and description of suspicious white man on train. Later testifies at trial about the racist encounter.
notes: Zane was publicly questioned by detectives (exposure unclear if at workplace or home, but treated as public based on detective arrival). He had sent threatening messages and had a prior assault conviction, making him a strong suspect. The threatening text 'you'll end up dead' was taken out of context. He was later called as a prosecution witness, where defense attorney attacked his credibility by bringing up his assault conviction in open court, adding to public exposure of the accusation.
